1311122222221111122221211112121212111122.content:
Minerva sighed in her sleep and hugged her pillow a little tighter to her chest.

A lively jig was being played by some of the villagers, and Minerva was laughing as she danced gaily. Her feet tapped out the rhythm lively as her hands swung her skirts around her legs. The three Von Eisenwald brothers were dancing in a close circle around her. They crept in closer and closer until one of them grasped her around the waist, hauled her up and around, and set her back on her feet. He smiled at her dazzlingly before giving her a sound kiss on the lips. Then, she was swept off to be spun around in a circle by the next brother. They all three kept spinning her around and kissing her, making her laugh and smile in delight.

Soon, though, the song ended, and Axelrod, Ferrus, and Augustus bowed to her gallantly. Then, in their bowed position, they slowly stepped back away from her, as did the rest of the people on the dance floor. The crowds parted, and a tall, blond figure moved forward confidently. Minerva smiled shyly and curtsied when the tall boy stopped in front of her and bowed. He took her hand in his and kissed the air above it.

"You dance divinely, Lady Minerva," he said in a low voice.

Minerva gulped and blushed.

"Do you have room on your dance card for me?" he asked.

"I always have room on my dance card for you, Prince Cassius."

He smiled brightly at her, then took her hand to place it on his shoulder. He placed one hand on her waist and held her free hand tightly in his other hand. Magically, the musicians began a slow waltz, and Cassius slowly began to lead Minerva in a well-practiced, elegant dance. Minerva felt like she was floating, safe and warm in Cassius's regal embrace. She sighed and rested her head on his well-muscled chest, enjoying the strong beat of his heart under her cheek. She smiled as she felt him shudder and stumble his steps a bit at her bold move. His heart began beating a bit faster, too.

Soon, she felt both of his arms come around her to hold her gently but closely too him as they slowed to a gentle swaying.

"Minerva," he murmured, and she felt him place a kiss on her hair.

She snuggled into his warm and comfortable embrace, feeling safe and content in his arms. He continued placing kisses on her hair, drifting lower to her forehead, and then around to her ear. He licked a warm stripe on the shell of her ear, making her shiver before gently biting it with his teeth. However, he then kept biting at her ear, nibbling at it over and over, until a harder nibble had her frowning.

"Prince Cassius, what are you...?"

In her sleep, Minerva batted her hand at her ear, only to have her hand encounter a large, soft, furry object.

She was suddenly awake, screaming! She sat up quickly, flinging her arm at the thing that had been nibbling on her ear!

"AAAAHHH! BUTTERSCOTCH!"

The rabbit, despite being rather fat, had easily ducked under Minerva's flailing arm and had hopped a bit to the other side of her bed.

Minerva put a hand to her pounding heart. "You silly rabbit! You scared me to death! That's not very nice, you know: nibbling on someone's ear when they're asleep! And you interrupted a really nice dream I was having, too!"

Butterscotch, his ears drooped sadly behind his head, hesitantly hopped back towards her, twitching his whiskers as if asking for forgiveness, his large, innocent eyes looking contrite.

"Aww," Minerva said, holding her arms out to the rabbit, "it's okay, buddy. Come here, all's forgiven."

Butterscotch willingly went back into Minerva's arms, luxuriating in the warm snuggles she gave him. However, after a minute or two of cuddling, Butterscotch wriggled in her arms.

"Alright, then. Enough snuggles for now, I guess."

Letting the bunny down on the floor, Minerva yawned and stretched her arms over her head. What time was it, anyway? Minerva checked her mantle clock across the room and groaned. It was still much too early to be up yet!

She snuggled back down in her warm bed, intent on getting another hour or two of sleep. However, just as she got comfortable again, that nibbling was back at her ear!

"Butterscotch!" she moaned, batting at the rabbit again. "Leave me alone! It's still sleeping time for me! Go bug someone else. Please?"

However, this time, the nibbling was more insistent, and a particularly hard bite had her biting back a curse.

"OW! Butterscotch! That really hurt! Stop it!"

This time, when she sat up, Butterscotch's demeanor didn't seem quite so easy-going or laid-back. He hopped a little ways across the bed, then stopped back to look at her, twitching his whiskers and rubbing his front paws together. He then hopped a little further, stopped, and looked back at her again.

"What?" she groaned. "Did you want me to follow you or something?"

Butterscotch then hopped off the bed and slowly made his way across the room to the slightly open door to her room. There, he stopped to look at her again.

"Fine, fine," she sighed, slipping out of bed, shrugging on her dressing gown, slipping her feet into her warm houseshoes, lighting a candle, and following the rabbit out of her room and down the hall.

Butterscotch led her all the way downstairs and into the scullery. Minerva wrinkled her nose. The scullery smelled funny. It smelled more like the barn or something and rather unpleasant. Then, she looked over to the corner Butterscotch hopped to. A ragged old blanket was all wadded up there, and Chocolate (the name Katie and Lucy had decided on for the dark female rabbit Butterscotch had brought back with him) was lying on it, her chubby torso heaving up and down rapidly. Butterscotch hopped up to Chocolate and rubbed his nose on hers, then glanced back up at Minerva. Minerva crept closer, wondering what was going on. Was Chocolate ill or something? However, when Minerva got close enough, she put a hand to her mouth and gasped. Then, she smiled and cooed in delight. Two tiny little furry lumps were lying behind Chocolate.

"Oh! Chocolate, you're a Momma! So, that's what you were getting me for, Butterscotch! I wonder how many babies you're gonna have, Chocolate?"

Thinking that Lucy and Katie would hate to miss out on seeing baby rabbits being born, MInerva got up and hurried towards the door of the scullery. She turned back right before she left to say, "Don't worry, Butterscotch! I'll be right back!"

Minerva hurried to the servants' quarters and found Katie's and Lucy's room. She easily woke both girls, explaining the situation, and both girls excitedly leapt out of bed to see Butterscotch's and Chocolate's kits.

"Awww...they're so tiny and cute!" Lucy marveled as she and Katie knelt down reverently before the ratty birthing blanket.

"Yeah. Miss Minnie, do you think we can hold them?" asked Katie.

"Um, I'm not sure. I don't think so quite yet," Minerva said. She wasn't any kind of an expert on animals, but she didn't think Momma's liked their babies being taken away from them too soon. "Maybe when the babies are a bit older. Let's let Chocolate and Butterscotch enjoy and take care of them for now, okay?"

Katie pouted but said, "Alright."

"I wonder how many kittens she's gonna have?" Katie wondered.

"Well, she's had four so far," said Lucy, "and the kittens are so small, and her tummy was so big and round...."

After another half hour, Chocolate had a total of eight little mewling kittens moving about her, wobbling around on unsteady little limbs. She licked them all clean and brought each one up to a teat to suckle. Butterscotch stayed by her head, rubbing his nose and tongue over head every once in a while in reassurance.

"Wow, eight kittens!" said Katie.

"What are we gonna name them all?" asked Lucy with a yawn.

Minerva chuckled as she helped both girls to their feet. "I think that's a question best left for tomorrow, girls. Let's leave Chocolate, Butterscotch, and their kits to sleep, hmm?"

"Yes, ma'am," they both said tiredly, as all three girls went back to their rooms to get a little bit more rest before starting the day.

1311122222221111122221211112121212111122.content:
"Mmmm..." Fortis said. He stared at a mountain of waffles in front of him, which he drenched with cream and syrup.

"You shouldn't eat so much, Forty! You'll get FAT!" said Eldonia, kissing her husband.

"Woman, I do so much work 'round this place that'd never happen", Fortis grumbled.

"Are you suuuure?"

"Weeell...Even if I didn't do enough work, with you around, i get plenty of...um...exercise..."

"FORTY! Not at the table!"

"Table, parlor, sofa, bedroom..."

"FORTY!" Eldonia squealed! "Quiet! Others might hear!"

Minerva entered the dining-room from the kitchen.

"Awww they're so SWEET!"

"Why thank you, Minnie!"

"I don't mean YOU, Eldonia! The two bunnies in the scullery just gave birth to rabbits!"

"Ooooh! Oh I bet they're all fat and fluffy and snuggly!"

"They ARE! Come and have a look!"

The two girls went into the kitchen and into the warmth of the scullery. Katie and Lucy were on their hands and knees, playing with the bunny-rabbits and stroking them, feeding them milk.

"Awww they're so CUTE!" said Eldonia, "Oh we should keep them! I bet Leo would LOVE to have a bunny all of his own!"

"He ain't havin' no bunny! He's gonna be havin' a dog, or a horse, or a dragon or somethin' worth havin'!"

Fortis had entered the scullery. "We can't keep the rabbits".

The two servant-girls stared at their master.

"But they're babies!"

"We can't keep them! Once they're grown enough, they'll have to leave!"

"But they're CUTE!"

"I DON'T CARE IF THEY GROW FEATHERS OF GOLD! THEY AIN'T STAYIN' HERE!"

The two young servant-girls stared at Fortis with shock! They knew that their master was a rough and tumble character with a brash personality, but they didn't think he was heartless!

They burst into tears!

"Oh now LOOK what you did!" said Eldonia, "Those girls are very attached to the bunnies!"

"Eldonia just TWO rabbits ate up my entire vegetable garden! If we have TEN rabbits, they'll uproot the whole damn forest! We CANNOT KEEP THEM ALL!"

At once, Fortis realised he'd made a mistake.

"How many can we keep?" Katie asked. Fortis opened his mouth...and said nothing.

"Damn it!"

Eldonia and Minerva burst out laughing.

"Ah, try and talk your way out of THAT hole, big man!" said Eldonia, poking her husband in the chest.

"I...You girls can keep the two big ones. And one small one. Leo can keep one. That's four in the house. That's more than enough! Perhaps Wolfgang might like one".

"WOLFGANG!?" said Minerva. She laughed, "Wolfgang isn't the kind of person who plays with bunnies, Fortis!"

"Not HIM you sponge-brained oaf! He's got two kids, doesn't he!?"

"Oh yeah..." said Minerva, blushing at her mistake.

"They might make a good present if they have one or two".

"What about the rest?" Lucy asked, "That only makes..." she counted..."Five! There's still five more!"

"They'll have to be sold", said Fortis. "We could give a couple to the orphans at the Abbey, they might like some pets. But the others will just have to be sold!"

The girls looked VERY upset. Fortis sighed.

"Listen girls!" he said, "They're REAL cute, but these are Fatlantean Forest-Lopers. They eat and eat and eat and eat! We'd never be able to feed them all! They'd be better off with other people who can feed them like they should be!"

The girls sniffed. Lucy hugged Fortis.

"Pwommis?"

"I promise!"

"...Okay..."

Fortis hugged the two servant-girls. "Now, they can stay here for a few months, but once they're ready to go, we gotta let them go!"

1311122222221111122221211112121212111122.content:
Zrrrrt-zrrrt...zrrrt-zrrt...zrrrt-zrrrt....zrrt-zrrt-zrrt-zrrt-zrrrt-zrrrt-zrrrt -zrrrt...WHAM WHAM WHAM WHAM!...WHAM WHAM WHAM WHAM!...WHAM WHAM WHAM WHAM!!! ...Aah...aaah...AAACHOOO!!...Wham!...

"OW FUCK!"

Minerva entered the cellar where her brother had a sort of woodworking shop. He was sucking on his thumb.

"Are you alright, Fortis?"

"I hit my finger with the stupid hammer..."

On a large table were lengths of wood cut into sections. Minerva hopped on a stool and saw that there were cages and wooden boxes and crates all stacked up.

"They're hutches and cages for the bunnies when we have to sell them", Fortis said. "I...I...AACHOO!!...Guurgh!...I'm nearly done wit the last one!"

Minerva stared at her brother, "Fortis are you alright?"

"Fine!" Fortis sniffed. "Go on! Get outta here so I can work!"

Minerva hopped up and kissed her brother on the forehead. She frowned. She pressed a back-hand to her brother's forehead.

"Fine, huh?" she said, frowning.

"I'm alright!"

--- --- --- ---

"You're burning up!"

"I'm FINE!"

"Nonsense! Always trying to act like a big, strong Mountain lord and look what that got you! You've got a fever...and a chill...and nasal problems...and spending all that time in that cold cellar!"

"It's a WORKSHOP!"

"IT'S A DEATH-TRAP! You want to die of pneumonia, young man!?"

It was a scene of complete opposites.

Fortis stood on the landing while his diminutive grandmother lectured him about the importance of good health. She walked around him, clucking and grumbling.

"Grandma, it's just a little cough!"

"It's nothing of the sort! Now you go and sleep! And lie down!"

"I'm not tired!"

"NOW!"

Fortis grumbled and stalked off to his bedroom.

Minerva closed her bedroom door as her brother passed, and opened her closet. She pulled something out, wrapped in paper, and left her room, carrying the package down the corridor into Fortis's bedroom. Fortis sat in bed, drinking hot, medicated sweet tea. He smiled weakly.

"Hey girl", he said hoarsely. Minerva smiled and approached her brother. She held the enormous package in her hands.

"This is for you!" she said, and handed him the package. Fortis smiled.

"Is this my yuletime present?" he asked. She nodded. Fortis ripped the paper off and looked at what was contained within. It was a dark, rich red fabric, soft and smooth, with gold and silk and large, shiny brass buttons here and there. He frowned.

"Uhhh...It's nice!" he said, trying to find something positive to say. "Um...what is it?"

"It's a dressing-gown!" said Minerva.

Fortis stared at the mess of fabric with skepticism.

"Um..."

Minerva sighed, "Get out of bed and see!" she said. Fortis chuckled. He got out of bed and stood up. He shook the whole thing out in front of him. Now he could see the robe in its entirety. It was about nine and a half feet long, and was a deep, rich mauve color, with gold-thread buttonholes, cuffs and collar, gold-edged pockets, and a large, gold-coloured cloth rope around the middle.

"Oooh..." he said. "Huh..." Fortis mumbled. "Interesting".

"Well try it on!"

Fortis pulled the robe on. It was thick and warm and soft, lined with silk all over, and was surprisingly comfortable.

"Huh..." he said, staring at himself in the mirror. It fit his arms, his shoulders, chest, back, and around the front, and it went right down to his ankles. Fortis pulled the robe shut around the front and held it closed with two buttons and the cloth belt. The robe came with three, silk-lined pockets, two down by his sides, and one breast-pocket up around his chest. Fortis nodded. There was even a matching maroon and gold nightcap to go with it!

"Huh..." he said. "Not bad..."

"Do you like it?" Minerva asked, anxiously. Fortis nodded, "It's good, girl...thanks!"

Minerva beamed, "Granny helped me make it".

"How did you know my measurements so good?"

Heaven knew Triton needed more than the usual amount of attention, especially since Gladius wasn't here anymore to play with him.

While her brother and her best friend-cum-sister-in-law, Eldonia, went to view potential house-servants, Minerva headed around the palace.

The palace at Ferramount was a rough, old fortress that over the generations, had been smoothed out. It was typically dark and heavy, even in the daytime, and the chambers and halls could sometimes seem cold and dark and unforgiving. She opened a door and entered a large room. A boy of ten sat on the floor, playing with blocks and a...

Minerva shrieked!

"Oh get it off me! Bad lizard!"

The small, blond-haired boy jumped up and hurried over to Minerva!

"I'm sorry Lady Minnie! HEY COME BACK HERE!...Bad dragon! Naughty Brimstone!"

"Is that yours!?" Minerva gasped.

"This is Brimstone. And this is Fyre".

"Fyre and Brimstone, adorable..." Minerva said, when the boy held up two baby dragons to her face.

One sneezed and a fireball shot out. She petted them gingerly.

"Might you have some pets which are a little less...flammable?" she asked.

"Oh I have lots of pets!" said Triton, "There's Hopkins..." he pointed to a fat, white bunny who bounced across the floor, in hot pursuit of a carrot that was rolling away from him.

"...and that's Cookies..." he pointed to a cat that was sleeping on the window-sill.

"...and this is Buckley!" he said. A bouncy, golden-retriever puppy yipped and yapped and yupped, and scampered over!

"Oooh!" said Minerva, "Oh he's a friendly fellow! Hello Buckley!"

"And this is Mortimer!"

The diminutive prince held up what looked like a brown pin-cushion.

"Awww, it's a...a..."

"He's a hedgehog!"

"Awwwwwwww!!!"

Minerva reached out and petted the hedgehog gingerly. To her surprise, the spines were not so sharp. It was like stroking a very, very prickly, fuzzy brush. The hedgehog shuffled slightly and blinked its tiny eyes.

"Awwww..."

Just then, the door opened.

"Alright Triton, I'm here! Now what do you wanna...MINNIE!"

Minerva jumped!...and let out a squeal of surprise when she accidentally squeezed the hedgehog too hard!

"Uh yeah, best not to try fresh-squeezed hedgehog-juice. It's very painful", said Cassius, reaching for the hedgehog in her hands, "Go on, Morty! Scuttle on now..."

The hedgehog toddled off. It had spotted ants around a lump of sugar in his little hutch, and was hungry for them.

"What are you doing here?" Cassius asked.

"I came to play with your brother! What are you doing here?"

"Well...I came to play with MY brother!"

"Could we play with your brother together?"

The two teenagers stared at each other.

"Uhhh..."
"Hmmm..."
"Well..."

"Hey Minnie! Look! This is Chirpy!" Triton burst out, holding up a fat, yellow canary.

"The royal zookeeper demands that we pay attention to his menagerie", Cassius said, flatly. Minerva laughed!

"And this is Stuart!" said Triton, holding up a pure, white mouse. Minerva gasped!

"Uh Tritey, I don't think Minerva likes mice..." said Cassius.

"She doesn't have to eat them!"

"No I mean I don't think she likes mice!"

"I...Oh...okay...How about bunnies? Here Hopkins! This is Hopkins!" he said, picking up a fat, white rabbit, "Do you like bunnies?"

"Oh I love bunnies!" said Minerva.

"Especially jugged, and served with sauce..."

"CASSIUS!! Not in front of Bunny!" Triton wailed. He covered the rabbit's impressive ears, "You'll scare him..."

Cassius sighed, "See, usually it's Gladius who plays with Triton...but he's off doing bodyguard stuff so..yeah..."

Minerva giggled. "I think he's cute!"

"Gladius!? Puh-leese!"

"No, I mean Triton! And how much he loves you!"

"Oh!...Yeah! Sure...but he can be a bit of a...Yes, Triton, Bubbles and Drippy are looking very fishy today...a handful..."

King Leviathan groaned as he got up from his desk chair and stretched his long, muscular arms far above his head.

"And I have these writs for you to sign, your majesty, and these documents to review, and these laws to revise and finalize, and--"

"Valerius!" the king said with a grimace to his royal page boy. "I have been sitting in this office all day, and I need a break!"

"Oh! Of course, your majesty! I'll just keep track of all these for you, and I'll be waiting for you when you get back!"

Leviathan sighed. "Valerius, what I meant to say is that I'm done for the day. Nothing in those piles of papers is so important or imminent that they can't wait until tomorrow. Go ahead and finish your filing and enjoy the rest of your evening."

The young page grinned widely at the king. "Thank you, your majesty!"

Leviathan chuckled as Valerius filed and stacked everything neatly on his own small desk and hurried out of the room before the king could say, "Mountania!"

The king wearily left his office and began his sedate walk down the corridors of his family home. He initially thought he'd head to the drawing room to spend some time with his family, but then he remembered that he'd grounded Cassius and opted instead to swing by the family wing and make sure his son was keeping in line with his grounding.

Leviathan shook his head at the thought of his eldest son's recent actions. Leviathan had to so rarely punish Cassius that he was still a bit surprised by everything that had taken place over the past couple of days! The king had never relished the thought of dealing with any of his sons' emerging, er, hormonal proclivities, but he had always figured it would be his often-disgruntled middle son Gladius that would be the first to engage in questionable acts with a girl. At least Cassius had confessed to using protection when he had taken Lady Minerva; otherwise, Leviathan's punishment would have been MUCH more severe!

The king reached the Crown Prince's bedroom and knocked on the door. "Cassius?"

When he was greeted with silence, he frowned and knocked again. "CASSIUS! It's your father! Answer this door!"

Leviathan opened the door himself and went inside. He scoured through the entire apartment, getting steadily angrier. "Did I or did I not explicitly tell the boy to come to his room and remain here for the rest of the day as the initial part of his punishment and grounding?! When I find that boy, I will whip his hide so raw he won't be able to sit for a week!"

The king then stormed out of his son's room and marched down the corridor, trying to puzzle through where Cassius would have gone. However, loud voices and laughing coming from his youngest son's room had him pausing.

"Aww, Minnie, there's no reason to be afraid of Creepy!" came Triton's voice through the door.

"It's a...it's a...SNAKE!" That was definitely Lady Minerva's voice!

Then, Leviathan heard Cassius's distinctive laugh and gritted his teeth. "Min, this snake is completely harmless! He's not venomous or anything! He's just a common garden snake!"

"But he's so...eeurgh! Scaly! And slimy looking!"

"Aww, but he's not slimy at all, Minnie!" said Triton. "See? If you pet him along his back here, he closes his eyes and looks like he's purring!"

"Er, well,...."

Cassius laughed again. "Bro, I don't think you'll convince Minerva about Creepy. You know that all girls are scared of snakes."

"I'm not scared of him!" Minerva said indignantly. "I just don't, er, um...."

"It's okay, Minnie! Here! How about Shelly?"

Leviathan opened the door to Triton's room and watched his ten-year-old son place a curly-q shell on Minerva Vanderstorm's hand.

"It's just a pretty shell, Triton," said Minerva gently.

"Oh, Shelly's just shy." Triton tapped the shell and suddenly several crab-legs emerged and tapped the palm of her hand.

Minerva shrieked and flung the hermit crab up into the air! Cassius laughed uproariously, and even Leviathan had to hold back his laughter at Minerva's reaction. Triton meanwhile ran hurriedly to catch the flying hermit crab before it could land on the floor and be hurt or its shell damaged.

"Shelly! Are you okay?" Triton gently ran his fingers over the delicate shell, and eventually the small, thin crab-legs re-emerged. Triton breathed a sigh of relief.

"Cassius! That wasn't funny!" Minerva turned glaring eyes to the Crown Prince, her hands on her hips.

Cassius just grinned at her unapologetically. "Yes, it was!"

Minerva rolled her eyes at the prince, and a small smile crept on her face. "Oh, alright. It probably was pretty funny to see. But, please, Triton! No more surprises!"

"Tri, do you even HAVE any more pets to show her?" asked Cassius with a frown. He'd never taken stock of exactly how many pets his brother had before.

"Hmm," said the diminutive prince thoughtfully, putting Shelly back in its glass cage. "Well, there's my frog Warty, and my tarantula Octo, and then there's all my larger pets that are kept in the barn outside! Like my baboon Butts, and my white wolf Snow, and my miniature pony Dwarf, and--"

Cassius held up his hands and laughed. "Okay, okay! I think we get the idea."

Minerva's eyes went wide, and she looked around the room with a frightened look on her face. She sidled closer to Cassius and grabbed his arm like a lifeline. "Did he just say he had a...pet tarantula?!"

Cassius smiled down at her gently and patted her hand reassuringly. "Don't worry, Minnie. Even though Octo's poisonous, he's never bit anyone. And he's kept securely locked up in his glass case over there."

Minerva looked to where Cassius was pointing across the room and breathed a sigh of relief, grateful to not even be near the tarantula case!

"Do you wanna go down to the barn and see my other animals?" Triton asked excitedly.

Cassius sighed unenthusiastically, but looked at Minerva. "My lady? I will leave the decision up to you."

Minerva looked at Triton's eager face and couldn't find it in her to turn him down. "Sure, Triton."

"Alright! Come on, guys! Follow me!"

As the three children entered the hallway, they ran into the king.

Cassius gulped at the firm look on his father's face. Whoops!

Leviathan crossed his strong arms over his chest and looked intimidatingly at his oldest son. "Cassius, I see you decided to ignore your punishment and leave your room to instead spend time with your brother and with Lady Minerva, whom I expressly forbade you to see. What do you have to say for yourself?"

Despite his fear of further punishment and being thoroughly embarrassed in front of Minerva, Cassius decided to own up to his behavior. He straightened up to his full height and threw his shoulders back, looking his father straight in the eye. "I admit, Father," he said in a slow, even tone, "that I did indeed disobey you and left my room. Triton asked me to play with him, and I couldn't in good conscience ignore his request. Lady Minerva just happened to come play with him, as well. I swear to you that nothing untoward or unseemly happened between us with Triton as a chaperone."

Leviathan was impressed at his son's words and nodded his head. "Good. Now, Triton, I believe you were going to show these two the rest of your animals?"

"You mean...I am allowed to accompany Lady Minerva down to the barns?" Cassius sad in disbelief.

"Yes. As long as you have Triton or another person in your company when you are with Lady Minerva, I will allow you to spend time with her for the remainder that she is here visiting the castle. However, once she leaves with her family, you will still be forbidden from any correspondence with her for a month. Is that clear?"

"Yes, Sir! Thanks, Papa!"

Leviathan smiled. "Go on, now."

"Oh boy! Come on, Minnie! You're gonna love seeing the rest of my animals!"

Triton insistently tugged on Cassius's and Minerva's hands and began to practically drag them down the hallways towards the palace grounds.

Leviathan just shook his head and chuckled at his youngest son's antics. He began to head back down to the drawing room where he knew his wife Athena would be waiting for him with a refreshing mug of Mountanian ale. Seeing Cassius interact and play with Triton and Minerva made him realize that he had been a bit harsh in his son's punishment. However, if Cassius treated his leniency with complete disregard, the boy would definitely be in for a whipping!

13111222222211111222212111121212121121.content:
The three brothers arrived at a secluded camp in the mountains around sunrise, led there by the many other young mountanian men in arms. The camp was hidden in the thick forests of  an isolated valley, where a clearing had been cut for a place to camp. Tents were arranged in a circle around a large bonfire, and on a bench in front of the fire was the famous captain Martinus, a 12 foot, aged giant who had led the Mountanians to victory against the Vladians in the last great war against them. Next to him sat two of his six sons, Marcus and Valor, famed generals in their own right who had grown up to their father's legacy, both figuratively and literally. Cannius, Jupiter and Fortis lined up with several hundred other soldiers in front of the aged giant. Martinus's booming voice carried over the entire crowd.

As many of you know, the Mille Electi Reges has once again been called to action in response to the Vladian threat. However, this elite force is not destined for the front lines. My son, Valor, shall explain further."

At those words, many murmurs ran through the crowd.

"Men, I know it is the greatest honor to fight on the front lines. However, we can no longer afford to sacrifice a tactical advantage for the sake of honor. For centuries, the Vladians have thrown their hordes at our borders, and for centuries we have sent our own boys to defend. These wars have always been destructive and have always ended inconclusively. I wish to end this meaningless slaughter. We shall no longer attack the Vladian's strongest point seeking honor in battle like fools, but instead we shall attack them at their heart. Instead of fighting their armies, we shall pull them out by the roots. We shall destroy their supply lines and attack theit capitol. We won't just defeat Vladia this time, we will end them."

    Fortis became filled with rage at Valor's suggestion of the king's chosen thousand being used for underhanded tactics, and bellowed

"You dare suggest that we use dirty tactics! We'd be just the same as the Vladians. The king would never disgrace his elite by having us raid the Vladian countryside like thugs. You are a disgrace to your father's

name."

Fortis's words were meat by many cheers of agreement, until Martinus began talking once again.

"You dare attack my son like that Fortis! Do you not know what the Vladians have been doing? They have raided our villages and have sent assassins throughout our land. They killed my granddaughter! Respect my son, he is right! If we don't kill them, the Vladians will kill us. Imagine, men, think about them killing your daughters, sons, wives. We shall not stand by and let this happen! Do not dare insult my name like that again, Fortis!"

    Fortis sat down in shame, biting his tongue, and the crowd calmed down with him. Valor resumed speaking.

"The Mille Electi Reges shall move stealthily through the wilderness from now on. We shall move north towards Vladia. Our goal is to capture the Vladian capitol of Brochka with a surprise attack in the night. Knowledge of our plans must be hidden from the Vladians in order for us to succeed. This may be the last time you contact your families for many months, and once we set out, noone may turn back. We will be living off the land. Shall you go?"

"Aye!" resounded every one of the thousand elite soldiers.

"Good! I would advise you write to your families now, this is the last chance. We have a trusted courier who will get the letters to them safely. Dismissed!"

     The three brothers began setting up their tent in an open spot in the clearing.

"What if those thugs that killed father were actually Vladians?" said jupiter,  "How is Minerva going to be safe without against them?" 

"Yeah if those thugs could kill father, there's no way that Minerva could stand up to them." added Cannius.

"Brothers, I think it is time we stop worrying about Minerva. It is time we trust her to take care of herself."

Fortis forced out those words, he really was the most worried of the three, but he figured that Minerva was going to have to be on her own eventually anyway, and there wasn't really anything Fortis could do about it while he was gone.

"Lets get some breakfast. We can't protect anyone on an empty stomach."

     The three boys walked to the bonfire, where many deer, mountain goats, birds, rabbits, and other local wildlife were being roasted, and grabbed a share proportionate to their large sizes. Fortis got a deer leg, while Cannius and Jupiter piled up on pheasants and rabbits. While he ate, Fortis got a quill and ink out of his pack, and began writing a letter to Minerva.



        We are sorry, Minerva, but we won't be abled to write to you while we are gone (it's top secret). Anyway, with your bros gone, you'll have to run the house yourself. There's rumors of assassins going around, so don't spend to much time in public. Anyways, we all miss ya, and we won't be coming back for a few months.

Sincerely, Fortis, Jupiter, Cannius



P.S. don't go through  our stuff while we're gone!





Fortis folded up the letter and placed it on the courier's table. Those damn Vladians were gonna get it for keeping him stuck out here so long!

    A knock on the door had Minerva rushing downstairs in hope of news. She opened the door to meet a courier.

"Ms. Vanderstorm, I have news from Lord Vanderstorm."

"Thank you!"

Minerva grabbed the letter and ran inside, shouting "Athena, Athena, their letter finally arrived! Come down quick!"

"I'm coming!" was the response as Athena climbed downstairs.

Minerva excitedly read off the letter, but her excitement turned to panic as she read its contents.

"Assasins, stay out of public? We're going to be killed!"

Minerva began to mumble nervously while Athena tried to calm her down.

"You know how your brothers are, Minerva! They think the whole world's out to get you. There, there, calm down."

"Minerva! Calm down! Panicking won't do us any good. I'm sure they'll be fine. We can take care of ourselves."

"How are you not worried about this?"

"Child, when you're as old as I am you don't get worried about hardly anything. Now could you go down to the market and get us some more soap? We just ran out this morning."

"Fine."

          Minerva got some baskets and also put a cloak on. Just because she wasn't supposed to worry didn't mean she shouldn't be cautious. With the baskets she walked down the road. Minerva made sure to pull the cloak over her head, to ensure that she wouldn't be easily recognized. In the distance Minerva noticed something quite odd. Meandering through the fields was a large convoy of carriages, chariots and soldiers. They looked to be military, but even from this distance something seemed off. Remembering being told not to worry, Minerva continued down to the village.

      The village was the centerpiece of the small fiefdom that Fortis was Duke of. Minerva had been down here many times before, and knew exaclty which one of the stands in the bustling marketplace she was looking for. 

       "Could I have 10 pounds of soap?"

"Yes, that'll be an ounce of silver." answered the man running the stand. He looked at her closely, trying to peer under her hood. Minerva hid her head deeper.

"Why Ms. Vanderstorm, is that you? What are you in disguise for?"

"It doesn't matter."

Minerva handed him the silver, and he weighed it on a scale to make sure it was the right amount, and then handed her the blocks of soap.

"I bet it's your brothers, isn't it?"

Minerva ignored his comment and started to walk back home. However, she, and the rest of the village, paused when the military convoy arrived in the center of the market. A young woman led the convoy. Behind her were soldiers and chariots. The soldiers did not bear the arms of Mountania, but instead a flag that consisted of a sprig of wheat crossed over a sword with a green, white, and blue horizontally striped background. Behind the military were hundreds horse drawn carriages filled with grains, livestock, and oddly enough, live plants. The livestock were unusually large and the live plants unusually abundant, and they looked to be imported from fatlantis.

     The young woman in the front was the first to speak. Her voice was quite loud and attention grabbing.

      "People of the Vanderstorm dukedom, we come to you from Denox to show you the future!"

     At her gesture, some of the livestock and live plants were carried over to the front by porters. 

        "These plants and animals before you were not imported from Fatlantis, but instead were grown on the harsh slopes of the Denokkian mountains!"

      This elicited some gasps from the villagers. Denox was the most westerly provice of mountania, and had the harshest climate and most rugged terrain. 

"Yeah right." called a villager from the crowd. "Those were obviously imported from Fatlantis, there's no way those could even survive in Denox."

"We understand your disbelief, but you must understand, these are no ordinary plants and animals. They were bred by our leader, Marina, to survive in the harsh mountanian climate. We come here to offer you these new crops."

     At those words, the porters carried a basket full of freshly baked bread and gestured for the villagers to come forward and take it. The man that had expressed disbelief was the first to try a piece, and his expression changed from one of doubt to one of delight.

"She's right! This isn't fatlantean grain, it's something even better!"

    With his confirmation, the other villagers rushed forward to grab some bread, including Minerva. The bread was indeed some of the most delicious bread she had ever tasted.

"Villagers, with these new crops and livestock, you shall never go hungry again! We shall no longer be dependant on Fatlantis for food, and the nobility will no longer grow strong off of the cream of the crop while you get the leftovers!"

Her announcement was met with cheers by the villagers. Minerva felt almost hypnotized by her words, she was throwing the whole marketplace into a stupor! Worried about the increasing excitement of

the villagers over the woman's words about "The nobility growing strong off of the cream of the crop." Minerva began to stealthily escape the crowd.

"The nobility grows tall and strong  from Your crops, and they use that strength to extort even more of Your crops! It is a vicious cycle, and today you shall finally be Free! And to celebrate your freedom we shall hold a feast! And we offer you now the seeds to these new plants and the best of our new animals!"

The crowd shouted louder, and erupted in applause. The carriages were unloaded of seed and livestock as the crowd surged forward. A sack each of every type of crop was offered to every villager

and in addition everyone got a pair of

livestock. As minerva slipped out of the crowd, she noticed that even the  soapseller was cheering for their "freedom", despite acting comcerned for Minerva mere minutes. Once she escaped the crowd, Minerva ran back to the Vanderstorm castle to warn Athena.

      As Minerva burst in the door ragged and breathless, Athena immediately ran downstairs.

"Child, what happned to you? It looks like you got chased here by a pack of wolves."

"Grandma..." she wheazed, pausing for breath.

"There's people.... that came to the village..... with a bunch of soldiers...... and food. Their leader..... she was this girl...... she was really good at talking...... and she got..... everyone..... in a stupor.... about being free..... from us!"

"Hold on, Minerva. You're saying that some random girl got everyone in a tizzy about being free, of us!, with some food. The Vanderstorms have ruled this dukedom for centuries with nothing but justice and kindness. You really think the serfs would turn on us so quickly?"

"You don't get it grandma!" Minerva shouted, having finally caught her breath. "That woman, she was from Denox, and she, she, well when she talked, it was almost like you were being hypnotized. I don't get how, but somehow she's managing to get them angry over nothing. I think she's been going from village to village trying to get the whole province riled up. What if she was sent by the Vladians to tear Mountania apart? They're going to kill us!"

"Calm down child. I'm sure this is all a misunderstanding. And even if it isn't, this castle is strong and secure. We have nothing o worry about.
131112222222111112222121111212121211211.title: The letter gets to Minerva 2 weeks later

choices: Hunting in the Tozhgovan mountains
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.content:
One of the things Fortis never got used to seeving in the mille electi was the fact that he didn't tower over everyone like he did at home. 

The mille electi reges were, as the name suggested, a legion of the most elite soldiers of Mountania, hand picked by king Leviathan himself. Among them, Fortis's 10 foot frame wasn't even average height, the typical electus was around 11 feet tall, all giants legendary for their strength, ferocity and cunning. The three brothers had all proven their worth to the king in the great barracks of Ferremount, however, in the legion Jupiter and Cannius were often looked down upon, being seen as riding on the coattails of their older brother.

After the first meeting, the different centuria had split up, each centurion giving their soldiers orders specific from Valor himself. The leader of the 8th century, Centurion Gregorium, a heavyset, 11 and a half foot tall man with an unusual

voice that warbled in constant anticpation, was currently giving orders to all the Decani of century XIII.

"One thing you must all understand, men, is that above all, this is a mission of stealth. Our spies have indicated to us that the capitol of Vladia, Brochka, is mostly undefended at the moment. If our movements our not detected, it should stay that way. For this reason, we shall make our way through the mountains of Tozhgova."

Gregorium pointed to the map.

"The Tozhgova mountains are some of the most rugged mountains in the world, and they run from where we are now all the way up to the center of Vladia. The mountains are so rugged that it would be suicide to send an ordinary army through them

to get to the Vladian capitol, so the mountains are completely unefended. Of course, we are no ordinary men, we are the strongest men of Mountania!"

"Aye!" resounded the Decani.

"And no mere mountains shall stand in our way. Your orders for the moment are to split up into your Contubernia and make your way to the valley of Pyolt by tommorow night." He pointed to the map.

"And await further instruction. For the purpouse of stealth, you are not to wear armor, nor anything that gives you away as Mountainian. The goal is to look like armed thugs to outsiders. Dismissed." 

The Decani split up to go to the tents of their own Contubernia. While Fortis was walking, he was almost knokced over by a powerful slap on his back, and he turned around in rage, only to back down as he looked up to the 12'3" frame of Darius, the third Decanus, his enormous muscles puting even Fortis's to shame.

"We hope tou don't get lost in the wilderness, Greenie. There's no turning back for stragglers, you know."

Fortis walked into his Contubernium's tent in shame. He thought to himself 

"So this must be what it feels like to be an ordinary person around me."

In the tent were all 9 of the soldiers under Fortis's command, who Fortis had been trying to get to know. there was Cato, a lanky, swift scout, Max, an oversized 18-year old who was the freshest of them, Calus, an archer who was rumored to be able to fire an arrow over a mile with his 9 foot longbow, Jonas and Temeritas, twins Fortis could not remember much about, other than them not seeming to take much seriously, Verres, the oldest of their group, who would've been Decanus had he not turned the offer down, and Jason, a reclusive man who seemed to spend most of his time brooding about one thing or another.

"Let's get moving, men, orders from Greg are that we need to get to Pyolt by tommorow night, and they aren't waiting for stragglers. Let's go, pack up! Cato, you scout ahead for a path!"

Cato dashed off at the order, while the others moved out of the tent to dissasemble it. Max rather awkwardly fumbled with the tent poles.

"Max, you're doing it wrong." said Fortis, quickly unthreading the pole and folding in in his hands. 

As Max resumed dissasembling the tent the correct way, Fortis piled his equipment into his pack alongside Verres.

"Kid, if you wanna make your pack look like it ain't full of swords and armor, you've gotta wad the blankets around it like this."

Verres took the pack from him and stuffed the blankets around his stuff in a messy but calculated way. When he was done, the pack, once bulging with sword tips and armor now looked to merely be stuffed full of floursacks. Of course, the illusion wouldn't hold for anyone who tried to pick it up, as the thing weighed nearly 200 pounds. Verres helped Jonas and Temeritas with their packs while Fortis finished cleaning up. 

"Why did you turn down the position as Decanus, Verres?" asked Fortis, curious. "You're the only one of us that's experienced, and you know what they say about greenies leading greenies, the blind leading the blind and all."

"I just don't have the conviction. You might be inexperienced, kid, but I know that we can count on you for guidance when the rest of us are panicked. You don't seem like the kind of guy that loses sense in the heat of battle. Most of the Electi get bloodlust in the heat of battle, they need guys like you to tell them what to do."

In his head, Fortis still didn't get why Verres turned down the promotion, as he didn't seem like

the kind of guy that got bloodlust, but questioned no further.

By the time Cato came sprinting back. the men were packed an ready to go, with Max being stuck with the tent, as he was both strongest and clumsiest. The men sprinted to keep up with Cato as he swiftly darted along a path only he could see. After about 15 minutes of running, the men stopped at a stream, getting a quick drink of water before moving on.

"I suppose I'm going to have to show you boys how to hunt." said Verres as they stopped by the stream.

"We're not going to see the rest of the century for another day, so we're going to have to come up with lunch on our own. Calus, I'm pretty sure you're fine, but the rest of ya look like the only wildlife you've hunted are the tame ones back at home. This is Tozhgova, the animals here are tough and hard to get, it's a whole new world compared to the hunting you've done at home."
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.title: Meanwhile, with the Mille Electi Reges

choices: Meanwhile, at the vanderstrom estate.
Reaching the rendezvous site.
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.content:
The eight contuberni  men were currently closely following the lead of Verres and Cato, carefully treading through a field of boulders surrounding a blindinlgly bright glacier.

"You see, men, the animals of tozhgova are far smarter than the dumb deer which wander around in the woods back home." said Verres

 "Down in the forest, the noise of our approach would scare off everything long before we could see it, so we must hunt the mountain goats from a distance instead. Show them, Calus."

        Calus extended the string of his enormous 9-foot bow and let loose an arrow with a loud twang. The arrow flew to its target, a mountain goat so far off that it was merely a distant white blur in Fortis's eye. His shot flew true, and the distant white blur tumbled downwards.

         "It will be difficult to get enough food for the eight of us. An Electi Reges eats for 10 anyways."

"I call dibs on the goat." shouted Maximus. "I don't know about you guys, but I can't go without 5 meals a day."

          "How'd a fatlantean get in the Mille electi? I beat you outate Gregorium at that banquet and he was so shocked he signed you up." joked Jonas, high-fiving his twin Temeritas as they laughed at their own joke.

"I'm still growing, you know. A big man needs a big meal." said the 12'3" soldier, indignantly.

       The contubernium continued treadig towards the fallen goat, being careful to not let their feet slip on the rocks. After Max draped it over his shoulders, they climbed down from the boulders into a thickly wooded valley, cut off on both ends by barren, icy slopes. The hair on the back of Fortis's neck stood on end as the entered the forest. The trees and undergrowth were far too thick, so much that the men could barely even slip their thick chests between the tree trunks. All of the undergrowth was covered in thorns, tearing through their calves. Most of all, it was utterly silent apart from them, not even a skittering bug breaking the heavy air. Only a few yards into the forest, the bright midday sunlight was replaced with green darkness, as dark as a new moon night. None of the men spoke as they crawled through, the heavy air sank into their lungs and bade them quiet.

       Cato continued to confidently lead the way, and the other 7 men followed, holding hands as not to seperate. Fortis, who was closest to Cato, whispered

"Are you sure we shoudln't have walked around? It feels like we're desecrating a graveyard."

"It's a 5 mile detour around this forest, through boulders and glaciers." whispered

back Cato,  "This way is much faster."

      The men heard a faint rustling that came from something other than them, and froze, staring at where the noise had come from.

"Keep going, men!" prodded Cato

"But where did that come from?" whispered Temeritas worriedly.

"It probably just came from us. Keep going, we have no time to lose!"

The men continued forward cautiously, huddling closer and closer in fear of the dark, silent woods around them. Once again, a rustling came from outside the group. This time, however, it was closer, but somehow quieter, like whatever had made it was deliberately trying to remain unheard. The men froze once again, even Cato. For several tense moments, nothing happened. No noise, no light, and a faint, musky smell was all there was this deep in the forest. Suddenly, a loud smack was heard and Jason shreiked in pure horror, violently torn away from the group by an enormous, black paw that emerged from between the trees.

"Get Jason!" shouted Verres.

The men ran after the spot in the trees the paw had come out of, tripping over the undergrowth. Fortis had the air knocked out of him as a black paw smacked his chest and dug into his flesh as it pulled him towards his owner. Fortis came face to face with a 16 foot tall bear with fur so black it could hardly be distinguished from the forest around it. Fortis began fumbling with his sword and stabbed the enormous paw with it, put its grip didn't loosen, and the bear instead slammed Fortis into a tree, crushing Fortis's chet until his ribs started to snap. But the bear's grip loosened as the other men began to ditract it. Maximus wrestled with it, wrapping his enormous arms around the beast's neck, while Jonas and Temeritas mindelessly sliced into its legs. Calus fired arrows deep into the giant bear's eyes as Verres slit its throat, ending the fight as the beast's blood gushed out onto all of them. Cato helped fortis up, and wrapped his bleeding chest with cloth from his pack. He then ran over to Jason, who was bleeding profusely. Everyone breathed a sigh of releif as the writhing beast finally went still, blood still dripping from its neck.

"Can you talk, Jason?" asked Cato.

"Yes." he breathed weakly. "Cato, I could tell that sound came from something following us, it grabbed me because it knew I could tell it was there. You should've stopped."

"I'm sorry, I didn't think there would be anything that could survive in this silent forest, there's no prey."

"I think that giant bear was the reason this place is silent." said Verres. His words gave all of them shivers. Jonas tried to lighten them all up.

"Well, I doubt there's room for two giant beasts in such a cramped forest."

"And think about how much meat there is on that thing." added Temeritas.

"And there won't be any maggots to spoil the meat." said Calus, "No flies could fly over all those glaciers to get here, and there's nothing for them to live on in this empty forest anyways."

The men nodded in agreement.

"Ok, lads, lets get this thing up to the glaciers, we need the beat frozen before it spoils. Jason, Fortis, you can hang back, of course.

"No, I can still help." 

Fortis tried to help them lift the

4 ton beast, but winced in pain as his broken rib stabbed his lungs.

"Never mind."

The men awkwardly struggled to carry the giant corpse trough the thick woods. The way out was far shorter than the way in, with the heavy tension out of the air, Fortis realized it had only taken them half an hour to get through the forest not counting the bear, the cove was only half a mile across, it was just impossible to tell from the inside. Once the men were out of the silent woods, they climbed up the bouldery slopes to reach the glaciers, and set the enormous beast onto the ice. Fortis, unabled to help carry the bear, had instead grabbed as many sticks and branches as he could for a fire.  He started the fire going with some flint as Jonas and Temeritas went back to the woods for more. Cato continued to care for Jason's wounds, while Calus, Max, and Verres began cutting up the enormous beast. Verres extracted the most valuable internal organs to

and tenderest portion of the meat to cook and eat for the night, while Max and Calus cut up the majority of the beast and the mountain goat into tiny strips, salting them and laying them out in the ice and sun to make impromptu jerky. By the time the sun was low in the sky, their meal was nearly ready.

"Why'd you keep the offal and cook it, Verres?" complained Temeritas,  "I'm not eating like a barbarian." 

"Quit whining, boy. Don't you know the offal is the most filling part?"

"Full of shit, is what it is."

"Shut it!"

     Soon the meal was sizzling in pots, pans, helmets, shields, and other makeshift cooking utensils over the fire. Fortis dug into the beast's heart, which was nearly as large as his head, while Maximus hoarded the intestines, slurping up the beast's small intestines, which were over a 100 feet long, like thy were noodles. Jonas and Temeritas only pecked at their food, not trusting it, while Calus and Verres split the liver between them. Cato

methodically fed the injured jason peices of the tender meat of the giant bear's flank, which Jonas and Temeritas stared at enviously. Cato also busied himself making bear grease out of the fat around its kidneys, drinking some of it for himself.

"Well, never thought I'd say this, but I am full!" boomed Maximus, the oversized rookie patting his newly round belly.

"Anyone want some?" he asked, offering up a shield filled with the leftover intestine.

"I do!" shouted Fortis, as he took the shield from Max.

"Could you get me some if that too?"said Verres. Fortis scraped some of the offal into Verres's helmet, and then dug in.

     Soon, all that remained in the sky was a halfmoon and the stars. Fortis layed out his 12 by 12 foot sleeping roll and wrapped himself tightly against the freezing Tozhgovan night, quickly falling asleepfrom his overlyfull stomach against the snores of his already sleeping comrades.
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.title: Hunting in the Tozhgovan mountains

choices: Sneaking through Vladia
Strange things be happening back home.
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.content:
The Contubernium woke up as the sun rose on the tozhgova mountains. The freezing nights of the glacier filled peaks would kill most men, but the enormous, thick and muscular Electi slept through the below zero night with only thin sleeping rolls, their prodigious body heat doing the rest. Cato was the first to get up, blowing a small bugle to arouse the others.

"Come on, lets go, we need to get to get to Pyolt before sunrise! Jupiter, Cannius, Maximus, start collecting the bear jerky in your packs. Everyone else, go help them, we need to move quickly!"

Fortis groaned as he stretched out his enormous body and rubbed his eyes clear, and then walked over to where the makeshift jerkey had been left out to dry. The sun and the ice had freeze dried the jerkey over the day and night, and now the 10 men had over 4 tons of rubbery bear meat to take back with them. Of course, no mountainian man would mind the flavor, meat was still meat to the voracious, musular giants. 

      With the enormous pile of jerkey finally collected, the mountainian men set out for Pyolt, each of them carrying over 900 pounds of the jerkey with them, enough to exhaust even the toughest of the king's chosen. 

     Cato, of course, was exempted from meat bearing duty. His job was to navigate the men over the shifting fields of boulders and ice that surrounded the hidden valley of pyolt, making steady progress until the mid afternoon.

"Come on, men, keep going!" urged Verres, leading the pack of lumbering, panting giants behind Cato.

"Remember, we get to eat once we reach Pyolt, so get your asses moving!"

The panting men made a half assed attempt to pick up the pace, cracking the crusty layer of frozen sweat collecting on their bodies, but soon slowed down to a snail's pace obce more.

      Fortis heard the crunch of reaking ice and a shout from behind him.

"Shit, shit, shit, shit, shit!"

Jupiter was trapped waist deep in a crevasse withing the ice, swearing as loud as he could in an attempt to ignore the pain.

"Damnit, Jupiter!" shouted Cassius, "We don't have time to be clumsy. Can someone get the fuck over here and help me get him out?"

 The men crowded around Jupiter, using all of their strength to pop him out. Fortis winced as his broken ribs dug into his chest at the strain.

    Jupiter finally slipped out, but the angle his leg was twisted was a dead indicator of his inablity to walk right further. He attempted to put his weight on the twisted leg, but retracted it in pain the moment it touched the ground. Jupiter fumbled for a solution to keep hinself upright, grabbing his longsword and using it as an impromptu walking stick.

          Hours later, as the sun began to dip below the horizon, the men reached the pyolt valley. Pyolt, like the valley of the silent forest they'd killed the bear in, was completely isolated from the outside world by mountains and glaciers, an ideal place for an private masse meet up of Mountainia's most elite soldiers many miles within Vladian territory. Smoke was rising from the forests beloe from countless small pits as the army camped out spread everywhere. The camp's were split up by century, so Fortis's troops stumbled into the circle of tents where the imposing figure of centurion Gregorium stood in the center.

"No surprise, the greenies are late. It looks like they've already have 3 casualties, and we haven't even had a single battle." jabbed Darius. His words were met with laughs from his comrades.

"Oh, we had a battle all right. With a giant bear taller than any of you." boomed Fortis, taking the beast's head out of his pack. The other men dropped their overloaded sattles full of bear jerky to the ground. The other men of the century could only look in shock at the fearsome thing cradles between Fortis's thick arms. The bear's head was as thick as Fortis's chest, an impressive feat considering that the 10 foot hunk's chest was larger by itself than the entire body of most mountanians.

"Dinner's courtesy of us tonight. A lot better than a couple of skinny mountain goats, eh?"

       A few minutes later, all of the men of the 8th century were gathered around Gregorium.

"Valor has ordered that the different centuries not know of eachother's battle plans lest one get caught and reveal all the others."

"Who cares what valor says." cried a soldier sitting to Darius's left. "Martinus would have us fighting the Vladians in direct combat, not sneaking around like weasels."

"Aye!" resounded the men around him.

"Did we not already disuss this? There is to be no insubordination! Valor may be a bit unscrupulous but from what I've heard he's a tactical genius. I expect precise obedience to his commands!"

The men murmured apology.

"Now where were we? Ah, yes. Century VIII's job is to masquerade as a foreign merchant caravan and wander through the Vladian countryside until we reach Brochka. Our goal is to get inside the city without suspicion and to attack warlord Dmitri's stronghold in the heart of the city while the Vladian's are distracted by the remainder of the Mille electi when they arrive to attack the walls. This is the most forward and dangerous role in the army. Whatever happens, we must not get caught. Are we ready, men?"

"Aye!"

With their breifing done, the men began to eat their dinner, Max passing out the bear jerky to anyone who wanted some, there being more than enough to go around. Darius and his contubernium shamefully refused the meat, having been upstaged by Fortis's men.
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.title: Reaching the rendezvous site

choices: Back to Fortis's troops
Continue with Minerva
1311122222221111122221211112121212112111.content:
"Goodbye, Mr. Tibbs! We hope to see you again when things quiet down"

        Minerva hailed off Mr. Tibbs as he departed the mansion for the last time. He was the last of the Vanderstorm's servants to quit.

      For the last three weeks, ever since the Denokkian woman and her convoy had shown up in town, the villagers had changed from being friendly to hostile. The woman riled them up, and now they openly decried the Vanderstorm name and had harassed their servants when they came downto market. So far, no one had actually tried to attack the mansion itself, but Minerva feared it was only a matter of time.

  "I can't believe the villagers would do that!"Cried Minerva to her grandmother. "Attacking a harmless little man just for working for us! Why do they hate us so much! What is wrong with them! My borther Fortis has kept his dukedom wealthy and secure, and this is their reward?"

       "Minerva, my girl, calm down." Consoled Athena, in the most maternal tonr she could manage. 

"You know they are not doing this out of their hearts. That woman in the marketplace speaks with an underlying and persuasive evil to her voice. It feels like Valleyan magic is enhancing her words, but something's off about it, I can't put my finger on it. Well, no matter, with no servants to go to the marketplace for food, you'll have to do it yourself. I'm afraid there's nothing we can do about it."

        Minerva groaned and went in her room to put on her poor person disguise. Almost a month holed up in a mansion had already taken the life out of Minerva's face, but she needed a tattered robe to finish the ensemble of a refugee. As Minerva had two weeks ago cut her long, raven hair into a messy black mane, with this disguise, she was nearly unrecognizable.

        Down the path to the village Minerva went. She made sure to approach the marketplace from a different direction than the path to the Vanderstorm mansion, so people would think she was yet another refugee coming from the North.

           Today, there was something new in the marketplace. The woman was still babbling on about how the villagers were mobilizing for some war, the villagers staring at her entranced, but next to her convoy was a squad of six fearsome looking soldiers.

      "Those guys sure weren't here yesterday." thought Minerva, Nearly drooling as she stared at them. They loomed as tall, even taller, than her titanic brother Fortis, but unlike Fortis, who stood tall, proud, and strong, these men had darting eyes and nervouse postures, ready to dart any minute. They bore scars all over their bodies, and their muscles were sinewy, knotted and battle tempered. She quickly turned around when one of them looked back.

       "Hey, look at that girl over there! A sight to sore eyes." Said one of the soldiers gruffly, elbowing one of his comrades. 

       "I could have some of her." commented another. "Blanca hasn't let us have any fun on the way here. This might be our last chance, boys!" 

      Minerva darted, trying to hide in the crowd, but her hood was grabbed by a large, outstretched hand before she could escape.

"You can't leave until we have our fun, now." her captor chortled, his strong hands preventing her escape despite desperate struggle. But his grip loosened as Minerva heard a loud cry of pain right behind her.

"Nivos, what is wrong with you!" shouted the largest and toughest looking of the men, most likely their captain, who had just given Nivos a strong fist to the face. "And the rest of you too! I can't believe you'd take advantage of an innocent refugee like that. Could you imagine what it's been like for her, a young girl travelig alone without anyone to protect her.

      "Yes, Commander Spes." they all replied, guilty looks on their faces.

    "Remember what Marina told us, men. She said we are fighting this war to end the tyranny of our monarchy, and to bring a new era of hope and change to mountania, and defeat the Vladians. Raping innocent girls will do nothing to this end!" Spes scolded.

        "Now, is there anything we can do to repay you?" said Spes, turning to Minerva and using a much softer tone of voice. 

      "No, I'm fine. I'm just heading to my uncle's place in Fantasmia."

       "Don't lie like that. Your a young girl traveling by herself in the countryside. And you're all skin and bones too. At the very least we can offer you a place to stay for the night. I doubt you are sleeping in inns every night." The towering soldier asked, his deep and soothing voice almost impossible to say no to."

      "No, I really need to get going."

"If you really have to." He replied.

       Minerva scurried away from the men and into the stalls of the marketplace. She got all the bread, food, and meat they needed for the week, thankfully not getting recognized, and scurried back to the Vanderstorm mansion under a midday sun.

       When Minerva entered the estate, she was met with a surprise. Two children, a girl and a boy, both looking to be around ten, were running around in the entrance hall, and Athena and some other, younger looking woman were talking in the dining room.

"Grannie, who are they?"

"Child, don't be so rude! This is duchess Lieben and her kids, don't you remember seeing her when you were little?"

13111222222211111222212111121212121122.content:
Minerva stared around the house. The handsome wood paneling lit up by candles and oil-lamps. Here and there, handsome, brightly-polished suits of armour stood on stands. On the walls hung large portraits of dashing knights, warriors and men. A glimpse into the family's past as a branch of Mountania's proud military aristocracy, which protected the peasantry and commonfolk, in return for land and money and favours from the king and his family.

Minerva headed upstairs, her beautiful gown fluttering on the stairs. She held a lamp in one hand, while candles burning against the walls lit the way ahead. She stopped at the top of the landing to look at all the doors.

At the far end, the Master's bedroom. A heavy black mourning-curtain was hung over the doors. Fortis had not yet taken up residence here.

Near to the master's bedroom was Fortis's bedroom, then Cannius's, then Jupiter's, then Minerva's. And then on the other side of the corridor, dressing-rooms, store-rooms and guest bedrooms.

Although Minerva knew that her brothers adored her and doted on her and treasured her and protected her and loved her and were always happy to do anything to please her...there was always one big payment that she always had to make.

She was never allowed in her brothers' bedrooms except in an emergency. She was never exactly afraid of her brothers, for all their strength and size, but she never dared to tempt fate and cross them!

But now the house was empty! She wanted to explore! It was just her grandmother, the maids and her friend Eldonia at home. And by the sounds downstairs, Eldonia had discovered the harpsichord in the front parlour. Minerva opened her brother Jupiter's bedroom and tiptoed in.

She lit the candles and stared around. The furniture was old, dark and heavy-looking. In the corner, she could see his work-table. Jupiter loved making models. He built houses and castles and all kinds of things. When she was younger, he'd built her a massive doll's house modeled after their real house! Minerva always found it funny that someone like Jupiter was able to do such delicate cutting, measuring, gluing and nailing. He was usually a bit of a klutz! But she supposed, alone, by himself, in a quiet little sanctuary, he could relax and indulge his passions.

Minerva then tried Cannius's bedroom. Here, she could see sketches for metal parts that her brother was hoping to make. Cannius loved metalwork. He had all these sketches on his desk about what he was going to build and hammer and bend and heat and shape. But the room that Minerva was most interested in was that of her oldest brother.

Fortis was now lord of the manor. Lord of the estate. Lord of the entire county. An entire slice of the kingdom belonged...in theory...to him. And it remained his so long as he was able to govern it as the king's local representative. One look in Fortis's room made Minerva think that her brother would not be having any issues with this.

The entire room was all about size and strength. As the oldest and tallest and largest of her brothers, the bed was massive. It had to accommodate his entire body, stretched out, so it was over a dozen feet long. The ceilings, as everywhere else in the house, were high and lofty. His wardrobe was extensive and here and there were weapons-racks and frames holding suits of armour. Most of these were now, of course, empty, having being called into service. Minerva stood in the middle of the room, taking it all in...

Thunk!

About what would happen to you and Cassius and Triton now that you're all one step closer to taking on leadership roles..."

Snort.

Their chins folded down, one over the other in three sloping rolls, their jowls, cheeks and chins melting into their round, broad, soft shoulders and their wide, heavy, sagging chests with enormous sagging, full boy-breasts that jiggled and bounced when they moved.
