King Leviathan, asking him to help with a skirmish on the Vladian border.
King Reginald of Fantasmia, asking him to broker a trade deal with Mountania.
1542.content:
"Ooooh," Prince Lucius groaned, pushing his plate away. He put his hand on his full belly and rubbed its rounded curve, encouraging a few good belches. "That was an excellent dinner, Eileen. Give Chef Joseph my compliments."

A young maid curtsied before the Lord of Laceton. "Yes, my lord. Right away, my lord."

Lucius sighed and slowly got to his feet. He leisurely strolled through his manor house to his private study and sank down into a large, comfortable chair by the fire. He poured himself a short glass of Mountanian whiskey from the always full decanter sitting on a side table next to his chair and quickly threw the drink back, enjoying the burn of the rich liquor as it blazed a trail down his throat and into his full stomach. He poured himself another drink, but left it sitting on the table as he closed his eyes and enjoyed his solitude.

The only problem with solitude, though, was that it made his mind wander and brood. He frowned when his thoughts inevitably went to events of twenty years past--events that caused a rift between him and his family, events that made him a virtual pariah to the Mountanian people. Thank goodness Fatlanteans were more forgiving and understanding, allowing him to have a place to live here in Laceton and still have some contact with his family as emissary; otherwise, he might be in Vladia of all places, trying to forge out a life with those greedy, awful slave-traders.

Lucius sighed again and ran his hands over his belly. He had been strong and fit as a teenager before he came to foster in Fatlantis. He had always had a good appetite, eating whatever and how much he wanted and never gaining an ounce. However, the food here in Fatlantis wasn't the same as the food he had in Mountania. The food here was richer, more fattening, and was always given in huge servings at least two or three times what was usually given in Mountania. Despite the amount of intense training he had been disciplined into doing every day, it couldn't make up for the huge amount of calories he found himself consuming at every meal. And the servants at the palace in Regis City didn't help, either. As soon as his plate was empty, more food would be piled on. Despite his protests at being full, he was always cajoled into eating more, seeing as he was a healthy, strong, growing Mountanian boy.

Lucius snorted. Growing was right. Before he knew it, he had a round pot-belly that wouldn't go away, clothes that wouldn't fit him anymore, and he had to forge himself new armor that would fit around his rounder, larger paunch.

His father Hercules had chastised him severely for his weight gain and had admonished him to "lose it or else." Lucius had tried, honestly he had. But he had grown to savor and enjoy the rich Fatlantean foods, even the feel of his stomach expanding and swelling when he ate more than he should. Plus, while his muscles had gained him a lot of attention from the maids and washerwomen in the Fatlantean palace, his rounding waistline had garnered him the attention from...someone else entirely.

Lucius shifted in his seat at his remembrance. He should have thrown off her advances. He shouldn't have been so flattered by her desire to watch him train out in the courtyard with his swords and knives--going shirtless in the sweltering heat of the Fatlantean summer, sweat running down his chest and his exposed, rounded belly. He shouldn't have gone on leisurely strolls with her around the palace courtyard. He shouldn't have let her feed him from a picnic basket until he thought he would explode from fullness. He shouldn't have allowed her to touch and rub his belly afterwards. He shouldn't have kissed her out in a secluded alcove in the palace flower gardens. He shouldn't have....

Lucius swallowed hard. His youthful indiscretions with the lovely Lady Danielle cost him everything by the time he was sixteen years old. Not that Lucius really had any desire to be king. He'd always known he didn't really have the temperament for it. Leviathan had always been more king material than he was. But to be denied returning home to his beloved Mountania except when specifically requested, to essentially being exiled in Fatlantis and denied contact with his family,.... Those were the hardest things Lucius still had to deal with. He missed seeing Leviathan's coronation, his nephews being born and growing up.

While Lucius still trained hard and regularly to keep up his muscle strength, his loneliness and discomfort with his depressive feelings had him seek solace in food--an ever present comfort here in Fatlantis. As a result, after twenty years, Lucius was quite portly, with a round gut that extended more than a foot in front of him to rest heavily on his thighs. His face was more rounded, and he had a slight double chin. However, despite the rounding of his body, he still looked Mountanian, with his height and impressive muscles. He still attracted attention from the opposite sex, like any hot-blooded Mountanian male tended to do; however, he steered clear of women these days. He'd learned his lesson long ago that women were trouble...and tended to get him in trouble, as he had a tendency to lose his head around them.

Lucius closed his eyes, and his mind was filled with the image of his teenage love. Danielle had had lovely, long, curly blond hair, sparkling brown eyes, and freckles on her nose. She had been eighteen to his fifteen at the time, and while she was the daughter of a Fatlantean earl, she hadn't been horribly chubby. However, she had all the aspects of a woman that had drawn Lucius's eye to her. She had been vibrant, witty, and full of life.

However, when she had discovered she was with child, she took her own life instead of having to face her father and the King of Mountania, let alone all of Fatlantean and Mountanian society with her indignity.

When the truth came out about why she had committed suicide, Hercules's justice had come swiftly. If it weren't for the fact that Lucius had made a favorable impact upon the royal Fatlantean court during his fostering, Lucius doubted he would have been made Lord of Laceton. However, the then king of Fatlantis was willing to show some compassion on the young Mountanian prince, though Lucius had been watched over closely as he continued as bodyguard to Prince David until he came of age to accept his Earldom in Laceton.

Lucius sighed. Despite everything, he'd had a good life here in Laceton, though it been a bit boring lately.

A knock came on his study door, interrupting his maudlin thoughts.

"Come in," he said pleasantly.

Eileen the maid entered and curtsied. "A missive has come for you, my lord."

"Ah, thank you."

Eileen handed him the letter, curtsied, and left.

Lucius's eyes widened in surprise and delight at spying the coat-of-arms stamped into the red wax seal on the letter. He unrolled it and read it eagerly.

Who was the letter from?
1542.title: Lucius--Lord of Laceton in Fatlantis

choices: None other than Achilles, Lucius's and Levi's younger brother.
Mordred, Merlin's father and Lucius's and Levi's friend.
15423.content:
Lucius recognized the wax seal embedded in the rolled-up parchment: two wooden, magical wands crossed over each other in the shape of an "X" and overlayed on top of a poppy flower, the national flower of Fantasmia. Lucius smiled as he eagerly opened the letter. He had always been on friendly terms with the young king of Fantasmia, and Lucius could only hope that Reginald wanted him to do something that would take him out of the boring state of affairs in Laceton these days.

"To Prince Lucius, Lord of Laceton in Fatlantis,

Greetings and Salutations to you, my friend!

I have a request of you in your services as Emissary to Mountania. My top counselor in wizard affairs has informed me that are becoming desperately low in our reserves of Douglas Pine wood. This is one of the heartiest woods out of which we make our wooden wands and has become more and more popular these days for its ability to retain its magical properties over many years of constant use. Unfortunately, my predecessors thought nothing of chopping down all of our Douglas Pine forests here in Fantasmia, putting us in quite a quandary of how to obtain more.

However, I have recently been informed that Mountania is literally covered in Douglas Pine forests on its numerous mountain ranges. Therefore, I ask of you, dear friend, to please bring our need for Douglas Pine wood before your brother, King Leviathan of Mountania. We in Fantasmia would be more than willing to offer nearly anything in exchange, as we find ourselves to be most desperate in our requirement of such a commodity. I ask, in all fairness, that you negotiate reasonably for our sakes, as we are willing to go as high as 100 sovereigns (or such equivalent in other commodities Mountania could use, such as mushrooms, potions, strawberries, or other such exotic and hard to find foods or materials) per board-foot of Douglas Pine wood, though we would much rather pay 25 sovereigns per board-foot.

I understand with the past history with your family, things might be rather...difficult...in your travels and negotiations with King Leviathan; however, I have sent someone along with this missive that should prove helpful in your efforts of persuasion with your brother.

Much luck and many thanks in your endeavors,

Reginald "Reggie" Magus
King of Fantasmia"

Lucius was excited! He had never brokered a trade deal between Fantasmia and Mountania before. This was just the sort of thing to get him out of his doldrums.

However, Lucius re-read the last line of the letter before letting it roll back up into a scroll. Reggie sent someone to help Lucius in brokering this trade deal? If so, then where were they? Who were they?

The door to Lucius's study suddenly swung open with a crash, making Lucius leap up with a shout, grabbing a dagger out of his boot, and entering into a defensive stance in two seconds flat.

The sound of laughter and the reality of just who had startled him, made Lucius frown and shake his head. He gently replaced his dagger and crossed his arms over his chest.

"I might have known Reggie would send you to help me broker a deal with Levi."

Who was sent to help Lucius with the trade deal?
15423.title: King Reginald of Fantasmia, asking him to broke...

choices: Lucius and Achilles stop in Regis City on their way to Mountania.
After several days, they stop at the White Castle to visit Mordred and Merlin.
154231.content:
"I might have known Reggie would send you to help me broker a deal with Levi," Lucius said with a shake of his head.

Achilles laughed and swung his long red pony-tail over his shoulder. "Well, who else did you expect Reggie to send, bro?"

Suddenly, Lucius felt himself being lifted off the ground and his torso having the stuffing squeezed out of him.

"A-achilles!" Lucius gasped, pounding his brother on the shoulders. "Let me...down! Can't...breathe!"

Achilles laughed again and put his slightly shorter, yet older, brother back down on the floor.

"What, am I not allowed to say "Hello!" to my favorite older brother, whom I haven't seen in a long time?"

"Favorite?" Lucius said with an eyebrow raised.

"Well, one of my favorites," Achilles said with a grin.

Lucius just rolled his eyes.

Achilles eyed his brother up and down before slapping Lucius on his large belly. "Seems you've gained a bit of weight since the last time I saw you."

Lucius scowled and swatted at Achilles's hand. "Stop that!"

"Ah, a bit sensitive about that, huh?"

Lucius rubbed a hand on the side of his full stomach and said, "Look, are you here to insult me or help me?"

Achilles laughed again. He went over to a sideboard filled with numerous spirits, poured himself a short glass of Lucian port, and flopped unceremoniously in Lucius's chair, all the while with Lucius scowling at him. "Oh, please," Lucius said sarcastically, "help yourself to my liquor collection and have a seat in MY comfortable chair."

"Thanks, brother! I appreciate your hospitality!"

Lucius rolled his eyes and settled himself down in the chair across from Achilles. He had forgotten how unrepentant and down-right annoying his younger brother could be at times. However, Lucius relished the company of the only family that had chosen to associate with him over the years. Achilles had never held Lucius's teenage misdeeds against him, unlike their father and Leviathan. Perhaps it was because Achilles had been too young at the time to really understand the situation and its complications, or perhaps it was because Achilles was too easy-going and playful. Achilles had always gotten along famously with anyone and everyone, making him a very likeable and enjoyable member of the Mountanian royal family. Lucius had always been grateful that at least someone in his family was still willing to associate with him, even though duties and responsibilities made it not very often.

"So, other than enjoying the food here in Fatlantis as you always have," said Achilles, with a sparkle in his green eyes, "how have you been, Luci?"

Lucius growled. "How many times have I asked you NOT to call me that?"

Achilles merely chuckled. "You know I only say it to get a reaction from you, and it always works! But seriously, how have you been? Any women in your life?" Achilles wiggled his eyebrows suggestively.

Lucius sighed and shifted in his seat uncomfortably. "No. You know there's been no one since...."

Achilles became serious for a moment. "Sorry, bro. I didn't mean to bring up bad memories. But, dude, it's been twenty years! You should have four or five kids running around by now, and you haven't even been married!"

"Achilles, don't start! Not again! Besides, since Levi's king and he has three sons to carry on the line, it doesn't matter if I have children or a wife or not."

"Maybe not, but I can see for myself how lonely you are." Achilles got a wicked grin on his face. "Maybe this trip home to Mountania is just what you need, Lu! It'll give you a chance to meet all the eligible noble women who would kill to get a piece of hot, royal Mountanian flesh like you!"

"Yeah, right!" Lucius snorted. He rubbed his hands over the long arc of his belly. "THIS won't garner me ANY attention at home, I assure you! Fatlanteans and Fantasmians, maybe, but Mountanians? I don't think so." Desperate to change this rather uncomfortable topic, Lucius said, "Well, enough about me! How about you! I still haven't had a chance to meet your wife and children, you know!"

Achilles got a goofy smile on his face at the mention of his family. "Yeah, I wish I could have brought them. They haven't been home since last year's Mountanian games. But I figured this trip would be too tense and political and short-lived to try and bring them along. That, and Livia hasn't been feeling well lately."

Lucius frowned in concern at the mention of his brother's wife being ill. "I'm sorry to hear that. Is she alright?"

Achilles grin widened in masculine pride. "We don't know for certain, yet, but I have a feeling she's pregnant again!"

"Well, then, congratulations!" Lucius said, holding up his glass to his brother as they both toasted the possible arrival of another little prince or princess into their family. As Lucius knocked back his drink, he swallowed down his envy. Despite his nonchalance earlier, a large part of him longed to have a son of his own.

"Are Troy and Paris looking forward to having a new sibling?" Troy was Achilles's oldest son, at eight years old, while Paris was five.

"We haven't told them yet, since we don't know for sure ourselves, but they love playing with Reggie's young children, so I bet they will be."

The two men paused to sip at their drinks. "Well," said Achilles, "enough small talk. How about this mission Reggie's sending us on? Isn't it ironic that a resource they are completely out of and in high demand for we have in spades in Mountania?"

Lucius shook his head. "I think it's horrible that past generations in Fantasmia had no thought of cutting down all their Douglas Pine forests without planting any new to replenish it!"

"I agree," said Achilles with a nod. "Such disrespect for the land would never have taken place in Mountania with the Valleyans always in residence."

The Valleyans were a nomadic gypsy people who had the freedom to roam and live as they wished off the lowlands of Mountania. Their way of life had been protected for centuries by the Mountanian royalty. The Mountanians, in turn, respected the Valleyans' beliefs in keeping the ground, flora, and fauna of Mountania sacred and protected.

"So, how much do you think Levi will agree to sell the Douglas Pine wood for?" asked Achilles.

Lucius shook his head again. "I really don't know. I'll try to make the deal as favorable for the Fantasmians as possible, but I doubt Levi will go any lower than 50 sovereigns per board-foot, especially since he knows Fantasmia is desperate for it. Ultimately, however, I have a feeling that most of the negotiations are going to be determined by Epimetheus."

Epimetheus was the current leader of the Valleyans, and as such would have the most vested interest in the trading of Douglas Pine trees between Mountania and Fantasmia.

Achilles nodded his head. "I think you're right on that account, brother, but have you had to deal personally with Old 'Metheus before?"

Lucius grinned in remembrance of the aged, but wise leader. "I have, actually, numerous times. Epimetheus and I get along quite well."

The Valleyans never condemned Lucius for what had happened with Danielle. The Valleyans have a much more open mind when it came to sexual expression and freedom, and they actually encourage their young people to experiment before they marry. Epimetheus had told Lucius that while it had been unfortunate that Danielle had conceived and had ultimately taken her own life, the Valleyans would merely have encouraged them to marry to make the child legitimate. It wouldn't have been the huge, explosive situation that Hercules had made it into.

"Ah, yes," Achilles mock-sighed. "Too bad we weren't born royal Valleyans, Lu. We could have experimented to our randy hearts' content when we were teenagers, as long as we took precautions, instead of the awful celibacy Ol' Pops forced on us. Unnatural is what that was!"

Lucius sighed. It seemed no matter how the conversation turned, it always led back to events twenty years gone. He shifted in his chair and blushed a bit. While he had certainly been irresponsible in letting his hormones get away from him with Danielle...it was only the one time. Lucius had been so mortified that he let the situation get so out of hand, that he had never been with Danielle or any woman again. His virtual exile from Mountania only solidified his stance of celibacy, despite the yearnings of his prime, teenaged body at the time...and the many long years since. Lucius was sure his brothers would consider him practically a virgin.

Achilles yawned and stretched his long arms over his head. "Listen, bro, it's been great chatting and all, but I've had a long drive from Fantasmia, and we have another long drive ahead of us tomorrow. I think I'm gonna go ahead and turn in."

"Of course, Acky."

"ACKY?!" Achilles rolled his eyes as he stood up. "Okay, I'll take that as payback for calling you "Luci" earlier. You know the nickname I prefer." He gave Lucius a large grin.

Lucius sighed and shook his head as he also stood up from his chair. "Yeah, as if I'd go around calling you "Kill." Some poor Fatlantean woman would probably die of a heart attack."

"Nah, she'd just swoon in wonder!"

Lucius laughed and patted his brother on the back as they headed down the hallways to prepare for bed. This journey to Mountania would certainly be interesting!

1542311.content:
"Achilles, I DO wish you would chop that stupid thing off!"
"Hey, my hair, my ponytail, my do, my decision".
"It looks terrible!"
"Hey, the kids think it's cute".

The two brothers clopped along on a lazy day, riding in a cart that was being pulled by a furry, cuddly-looking shire-horse. It clopped sleepily along, swishing its tail around and moving so slowly, it might have been sleepwalking. The two Mountanian princes didn't mind. They were nearly at their destination anyway.
