15423111.content:
As Lucius and Achilles entered they were greeted by a bubbly.

"OMG! It's the Lord of Laceton and his brother Achilles!" The maid squealed in delight. "Have you gained weight Lord Lucius? If you keep up the weight gain you'll be one the most handsome men in Fatlantis."

Lucius blushes with embarrassment. Achilles and the maid start laughing.

"Come on Luci, don't get embarrassed. She was only trying to cheer you up." Achilles said while chuckling.

"I bet you nice lords are here to visit His Royal Loftiness and his family would love to have you stay for while. Currently Merlin from White Castle is also visiting to test his new products. For a kid he's by far the smartest that I met. He even tutors the young lords. Follow me to the dining room. My Master and his family are about to begin breakfast. I know you two might have important business but feel free to stay here as long as necessary."

The hefty maid curtsies and starts walking at a rather fast pace for someone her size, but it's not difficult for the brothers to keep up with her. As she walked her red hair, which was tied into a bun, bounced with as much enthusiasm that she had while she walked. The maid leads Lucius and Achilles to a large door. The maid starts knocking on the door.

"Who is it?" Asked a jolly and booming voice.

"It's Honey m'lord. Two more surprise visitors are here to see you."

"Who are they?" David asked.

"They are Lucius Lord of Laceton and Lord Achilles sire."

"Let them in. They always make a family meal more lively."

"As you wish Master." Honey said as she opened the door.

As the door opened four large people were seated at a large table. King David was about the same height as Leviathan, Lucius's middle brother and obviously his father's son. He had fiery red hair contrasted with his cool blue eyes. The six ton king hoisted himself up and walked over to the two Mountainian lords. Surprising ly King David moved rather gracefully for a man of his size, but that was due to the workout habits that he developed thanks to Lucius and it was also the sole reason why he weighed so much combined with his love for Fatlantean Sumo Wrestling.

"What brings you here my good friend. I see your position as ambassador has been doing wonder, yet I was hoping you would of gotten a bit bigger." Davids said as he playfully teased Lucius about his weight.

"So I guess the King of Jokesters hasn't lost his touch." Lucius countered in a fake mocking tone.

David gives a short belly laugh before he continues the conversation.

"Now that's my dear friend that I know. Have you found a lover yet?"

Lucius flinches as he remembers the series of events with Danielle. David realizes that he might have pried into an old wound that hasn't fully healed.

"You're still not over that? I guess it doesn't help that the royal records are extremely inconsistent from that unfortunate day, but please take a seat and join us for a meal. Honey, can you play us a tune that can help brighten the mood? I'm afraid I have accidentally reminded him of a painful memory."

"As you wish Your Majesty."

Honey retrieves her violin and starts playing a beautiful Fatlantean tune. Now Queen Isobel stood eight feet tall and weighed significantly less than her husband at only half his weight. David's two 15 year old boys, weighed merely five pounds over half a ton and stood seven feet high thus making them taller than previous princes in the Fatlantean royal family for their age. Lucius talked to the royal family and the young talented Merlin during the duration of breakfast and also ate his fill if not more.
15423111.title: Meeting the Fatlantean Royal Family

choices: David challenges Lucius to an eating contest to see how much capacity Lucius has
At Lunch Lucius combines working out with eating due to the adrenaline rush
154231111.content:
Cameron, Edmund and Merlin were starting to get bored by the talking that all of the adults were doing and morning dessert was not ready due to the royal kitchen running out of chocolate sauce that can be applied to it.

"Man I'm bored. I wish dessert was ready so I can be able to eat." Cameron groaned.

"Me to bro." Edmund yawned.

"Looks like I'll have to provide a solution. I've been meaning to give this new custard I made a try, but I need the perfect test subject." Merlin whispered to the heavy princes.

"Is that weight gain custard. The sooner I reach a ton the better." Cameron whispered as stared at the dark brown bottle that Merlin conjured up.

"I won't you or your father try it yet. I was hoping for a different subject. Someone from a culture that isn't focused on weight gain." Merlin whispered as a mischievious smile appeared as he looked at Lucius.

"The Lord of Laceton? I'm not sure if he'll want to do it if you inform him that it is weight gain custard." Edmund whispered to Merlin.

"Actually I wasn't planning on telling him." Merlin whispered before a small grin appeared on his face.

The youngsters are disrupted as a few maids and butlers came in carrying a several pies.

"Forgive us your majesty for we did not have any chocolate sauce to go with the cream pie. We had some last night, but I think someone ran off with the bottle and drank it all up." a butler said as he did a short bow.

"I think I have just the thing. I happened to bring some chocolate with me from home." Merlin said as he tried to refrain from laughing.

David raises an eyebrow with suspicion.

"Izzy, I think that may be weight gain custard." David whispered as he glanced at the dark brown bottle that Merlin was holding.

"How lovely, I've been meaning to put on some weight."

"I don't think he's going to give us some yet and I think Achilles can see through this obvious prank."

"What makes you think it's a prank?"

"Do I have to mention the kids. Just look at them looking at the bottle in anticipation. I think they're going to attempt to give it to Lucius." David whispered as Merlin walked over to the Lord of Laceton.

"Should we do something dear?" Isobel whispered with concern.

"Not at all, I'll anxiously watch to see if their scheme blows up in their faces. If it succeeds then I may have a little prank of my own to pull. Sometimes it is better to give someone a taste of their own medicine." David said as a naughty smile formed.

David whispers his plan. They then make out and watch as they pretend to be unaware of the prank.

"Lord Lucius would you like some chocolate sauce with your cream pie. It's a rich dark chocolate sauce that will set taste buds on fire." Merlin said while holding onto the bottle.

"Sure, I love dark chocolate."

Merlin pours some of the custard to the cream pie that was in front of Lucius.

"Does anybody else want some?" Merlin asked.

The others say no since they know it is a prank. Lucius takes a bite out of the cream pie. A burst of flavor dances in his mouth. Lucius starts to experience a rush of adrenaline flow through his body before he clutches his stomach as a hunger pain took over. His stomach started to growl loudly.

"That was delicious, but why do I feel so hungry. Can I have some more pie?" Lucius said as he started drooling.

Lucius starts grabbing a few more pies and starts applying more of the weight gain custard to them. Merlin stops laughing as he realizes that Lucius was consuming more custard.

"Um guys, I think I miscalculated the side effects of the custard and its potency."

"What do you mean?" Cameron asked.

"Um, bro.? Remember we were complaining about not getting dessert. I think the Lord of Laceton just ate every pie."

Both Fatlantean princes look on in disappointment as Lucius starts chugging the last of the custard. They then notice their father laughing hysterically.

"I think we're busted. I can't believe we jipped ourselves of dessert and father will probably leave us here while he and mother go out for icecream."

"Please Ed, don't remind me. Father usually let's us punish ourselves. It's so embarrassing when he does."

"I'm... I'm sorry Lucius but I think Merlin and my boys tricked you into consuming weight gain custard." David says as he tries to stop laughing.

"That explains the hunger, but not the adrenaline rush. Is there more food. I feel like I haven't eaten in months."

"Well there goes staying only one day. Hey Merlin how long will the effects last? My brother needs to broker a deal in Fantasmia and my bro. Levi is a very impatient man when it comes to trade agreements."

"Unfortunately I don't know. This was a new type of custard all together. I was expecting him to literally down the whole bottle. I'll need to document the effects it has on Mountainians before I can make some to be sold in Fatlantis."

"Oh, then I guess we'll have to take you along with us."

"Let's go out for some ice cream. There's a new dessert buffet where the dessert magically replenishes itself." David said.

"Can we go father?"

"Not until you clean the dishes and clean your rooms."

"What? But, isn't that why we have maids and butlers?" The fatlantean princes ask.

"Yes, but I just gave them all an hour break just now."

"But it will be lunch by the time we get done!" the princes moaned.

"You should of thought of that before you conspired with Merlin to pull a practical joke on Lucius. If you get done then maybe you can have dessert."

Lucius and his friends leave for the dessert buffet while Cameron, Edmund, and Merlin are left to do cleanup duty.
154231111.title: Lucius Consumes Weight Gain Custard

choices: Mischievous Merlin plays a prank on Achilles at dinner!
Morgaine is seated next to Lucius, and she gives him a palm-reading.
1542312.content:
A large black carriage marked with the Mountanian royal seal sped along the gravel, dirt roads of Fatlantis, pulled by four muscular, black, snorting stallions.

While King Reginald had not said that he wanted the trade negotiations with Mountania to happen as soon as possible, Lucius got the impression from Reggie's letter that since Fantasmia was in dire need of Douglas Pine wood, the sooner he and Achilles got to Mountania and worked out an agreement with Levi, the better. Therefore, their carriage stopped as little as possible, merely for food and rest breaks and for exchanging the horses at inns along the way. They didn't even stop at night, as they had the drivers swap each other out in shifts while Lucius and Achilles made themselves as comfortable as they could and slept inside the speeding carriage.

"Really, brother, the White Castle is practically in Mountania and only a few hours away from Ferramount!" said Achilles. His usual joking mood was waning in the light of Lucius's insistence on getting to Mountania as soon as possible. "My body is tired from sitting in this carriage for three whole days without stopping! Besides, we'll be driving RIGHT BY the White Castle. What would Mordred think if his good friends, the princes of Mountania, are in such a hurry to commence with a trade deal concerning HIS OWN COUNTRY that they can't be bothered to even come in and visit with him for an evening? I would think he'd consider it a slight, wouldn't you?"

Lucius sighed and shifted his own tired buttocks on the carriage seat he had been sitting on for too many hours straight. Achilles had a point...well, many of them. "Alright, alright! We'll stop in and see Mordred and his family."

Achilles gave Lucius a blinding smile, leaned over to the other side of the carriage, and give his brother a smart kiss on the lips! "MUAH!"

"Eeeeeew! Achilles!" Lucius dug out his handkerchief and wiped his lips, scowling at his brother the whole time. However, Achilles was already excitedly leaning out the carriage door window to speak to the drivers about stopping at the White Castle for the night. Lucius couldn't possibly miss the enthusiastic cheers of the four men. He grimaced at himself. Had he really driven everyone so hard in his eagerness to get to Mountania and out of the boredom his life had become?

When Achilles settled back in his seat, still grinning like a loon, Lucius cleared his throat. "I'm...sorry, Achilles. I didn't mean to drive everyone so hard!"

"Ah, nothing to worry about! The men know you're excited to go home after having been away for so long!"

Within the hour, the carriage was pulling up to a large, imposing castle made completely of white blocks of stone. It gleamed in the late afternoon sunlight. Lucius had seen the castle several times before, but never this close up. It was absolutely beautiful. Occasionally, a rainbow of colors would wave over the castle from top to bottom, just emphasizing the beauty, majesty, and magical nature of the castle and its residents.

As the carriage moved over the drawbridge into the castle proper, Lucius shivered as he felt like his body had just moved through an inch of freezing cold water!

Achilles laughed. "I forgot to tell you about that! Those were their protection wards we just passed under. It keeps anybody with evil intent out of the castle. It chills you right down to the bone for a second as you pass through them."

"So, they merely have magic protecting their castle?"

"Of course not! If you look closer, you'll see all manner of defenses and guards and bowmen positioned around the castle battlements. But since they have magic at their disposal, why not use it?"

The carriage went through a large courtyard and stopped at the far side. Five people were already standing by the large double doors of the castle waiting to greet them, all dressed in wizarding robes that had various celestial bodies imprinted on the fabric.

Achilles, grinning from ear to ear, leapt from the carriage before it was completely stopped and laughed as he engulfed a tall man with shoulder-length black hair.

"Mordred, old friend! How are you? It's so good to see you! It's been far too long since you've last been down in Fantasmia!" Achilles gushed.

Mordred laughed and pounded his friend on the back. "Achilles, I was just there last week!"

"See? Far too long! A day is too long without having you around to play pranks on our old friend, Reggie!"

Lucius hesitated coming down as he saw how easily Achilles got along with everyone. Would he receive the same warm welcome, despite everything he'd done?

Lucius took a deep breath and slowly descended from the carriage. He stood awkwardly in front of Mordred's family, but they were all smiling at him. Mordred stepped forward and bowed. "Your royal highness! I'm so glad you decided to stop here and visit with us! It has been a long time, my friend!"

Lucius immediately felt more at ease and smiled back at the shorter man. He took Mordred's hand and shook it with a strong handshake. "It's a pleasure to see you! Achilles was begging me to stop here for the night, and I'm glad that we did."

"Hey, you were getting just as tired of being in that carriage as I was!" said Achilles.

Everyone laughed.

"I don't believe you've met all of my family, your highness," said Mordred.

"Please, call me Lucius."

"Lucius," Mordred said with a nod of his head. He moved to a lovely woman with long, straight brown hair, who had her arm linked with Achilles's. "This is my wife, Viviane."

"Pleased to meet you, Lucius," Viviane said, holding out her hand to Lucius, who kissed the air above it.

"Next to her is my son, Merlin."

"Hi!" said Merlin with a wave of his hand. "I didn't know Cassius, Gladius, and Triton had another uncle!"

Lucius sighed, and Mordred looked at Merlin sharply. "Merlin, we don't speak of things that upset other people!"

Merlin frowned. "But how was I supposed to know it would upset Lucius? Besides, I've seen Achilles loads of times, and he never mentioned Lucius, either!"

"Merlin, you will--"

"Mordred," said Lucius softly, laying his hand on Mordred's arm. "It's okay." Turning to Merlin, Lucius said, "I did some things when I was young that I'm not very proud of, and my family is still angry at me for them."

"But, why--"

"Merlin, that's enough!" said Mordred. "You've embarrassed our guest enough for tonight!"

Merlin flushed and looked down at his feet. "Sorry, Papa."

Mordred shook his head.

Lucius felt a tugging on his pants, and he looked down to see a lovely blond girl about seven years old. Lucius smiled and squatted down so he was eye level with her. "Hi. I'm Lucius. What's your name?"

"I'm Igraine," the girl said softly.

"That's a pretty name...for a pretty girl."

The girl blushed sweetly, then bravely put her hand on Lucius's bicep, feeling the strength of the muscles in his arm.

"Are you really strong?" she asked.

"I certainly try to be."

"Have you ever found a Luck Dragon before? I bet you could find one and not get hurt...."

"Igraine!"

Lucius looked up to see a woman with long black hair swoop down to her daughter. The little girl curled up in her mother's arms and began to cry softly.

Lucius had no idea what had just happened. "I'm...I'm so sorry!" he said helplessly.

The woman looked back up at Lucius, and Lucius had to catch his breath. This woman was breath-takingly beautiful, from her dark blue, soul-deep eyes, long oval-shaped face, high cheekbones, ivory skin, and a bounteous bosom to which she was holding Igraine. Lucius hadn't been so taken with such a lovely looking woman in a long time. He quickly stood up, a blush suffusing his cheeks.

"It's not your fault, your highness," said the woman, as she gently stood up as well, still clutching Igraine to her. "My husband, Lancelot, passed away recently when he and several others were on an expedition to find a Mountanian Luck Dragon. Unfortunately, luck was not with him as the dragon crept up behind him. Igraine is still taking her father's death rather hard, even though it was several months ago, now."

Mordred leaned in and whispered to Lucius, "Lancelot barely turned in time with his wand in hand, but the dragon had already blown a great plume of fire at him. Burned him to a crisp. We barely had any remains to bury for poor Morgaine and Igraine. They had no other place to stay, so I have invited them to live here with me."

Morgaine. That was the lovely woman's name. Lucius couldn't conceal his horror at learning of Lancelot's awful death, however. "Morgaine, I am so sorry for your loss! How awful for you and your daughter!"

Morgaine nodded her head. "Thank you for your condolences, Sir."

"Well, I don't know about you, brother," Achilles broke in, hoping to ease the tense atmosphere, "but that long carriage ride made me famished!"

Lucius rubbed a hand on his large, round belly, blushing a bit as it growled. Everyone chuckled.

"Come, my friends," said Mordred. "Let us dine together this eve and enjoy fellowship like old times." Mordred held out an arm in invitation, and everyone entered the White Castle for supper.
1542312.title: After several days, they stop at the White Cast...

choices: Lucius sneaks down to the kitchens after everyone's in bed.
Morgaine invites Lucius for a snack in the drawing room.
15423121.content:
"I'll be just a minute, Papa," Merlin said as everyone was heading to the main dining hall. "There's something I forgot up in my rooms."

Mordred frowned at his son, but nodded his head. "Alright. But be quick about it!"

"I will!"

Merlin took his wand out of his robe pocket, swished it over his body, and he instantly vanished from the main hallway only to reappear a second later in his rooms. He went over into a small, well-ventilated room off his bedroom that he used strictly as his potions laboratory. Learning to produce good quality potions from books, as well as design new ones, was a technique taught to all wizards-in-training. Merlin had always had a fair hand at potion-making, and he had come up with several that he thought might make good pranking material. His father had regaled him since he was little with stories about all the hi-jinks he and Achilles got up to with King Reginald down in Fantasmia. Well, Merlin wanted to make his mark on the pranking scene and see if he could measure up to his father's and Achilles's standards.

Having just met Prince Lucius and feeling the prince was rather uncomfortable in his interactions with Merlin's family, Merlin knew better than to try anything on Achilles's oldest brother. Achilles and his father, Mordred, however, were fair game!

Merlin opened his cupboard where he stored his already made potions. There were so many good ones to choose from! Which would be best for his father, and which would be best for Achilles? Merlin eventually decided on the two potions he wanted to use, closed up his cupboard, waved his wand, and in a flash of blue light, he appeared just outside the dining hall doors. He peeked inside to see everyone sitting at the table, talking and enjoying their first course of appetizers. Merlin smiled. Perfect! He held the first bottle of potion in his left hand, muttered a few words, tapped the bottom of the bottle with his wand, and the level of liquid in the bottle fell about an inch. He did the same to the second bottle before stowing them both in a pocket of his robes and then proceeding into the dining hall.

"Ah, Merlin!" his father said as he approached the table. "There you are! Did you find what you were looking for?"

"Yes, Papa, I sure did," Merlin responded with a smile that bordered on a smirk. He noted with satisfaction that both Mordred and Achilles were taking several sips from their goblets of ale, neither the wiser that they were now drinking a potion-laced beverage. Merlin took his seat between his mother and Igraine, and a servant promptly placed a plate filled with food in front of him. His father was at the head of the table, with Achilles on his right and Lucius next to him. Morgaine, as his father's younger sister, sat at the opposite end of the table.

"What would the young master care to drink this evening?" asked the servant at his elbow.

"Some lemonade would be just fine for me, thank you."

"Are you sure you want lemonade, Merlin?" asked Achilles from across the table. "Surely you're old enough now to enjoy some mead or ale."

Merlin merely smiled and accepted his goblet of 'children's drink.' "Of course, Uncle Achilles. I just feel like lemonade tonight."

Achilles smiled at him in return, but the twinkle in his green eyes made Merlin wonder. "Suit yourself," Achilles said with a shrug.

"So, Reggie's sending you both to Mountania for a trade negotiation, hmm?" asked Mordred, as the second dinner course was being served.

"Yes," said Lucius, as he plowed through his plate as if he were starving. "Apparently, Fantasmia is in desperate need of Douglas Pine wood for wand-making."

Mordred sighed, shaking his head. "That doesn't surprise me in the least."

"Nor I, brother," said Morgaine with a sad look on her face. "How our ancestors could have been so careless with such a precious natural resource astounds me."

"Yes. However, I'm also disheartened that so much stock is being put in Douglas Pine wood as THE WOOD for wand-crafting. There are so many excellent woods out there for making wands, and they all have their advantages and disadvantages. This pressure of everyone wanting a Douglas Pine wand is just a fad, mark my words! In a year's time, it will be a different wood that everyone will be clamoring to have their wands made of. This whole thing is utter rubbish!"

"I quite agree, brother," said Morgaine. "However, I know Lancelot had a Douglas Pine wand, and I can certainly see why it's being touted so highly right now. My own wand, though, is made of cherry and performs much better for me than Lancelot's ever did."

"So, let me get this STRAIGHT!" Achilles frowned. His voice suddenly squeaked really high. Merlin swallowed a chuckle and dabbed his mouth with his napkin to hide his grin. Achilles cleared his throat and said, "This trade deal with Mountania will probably only be needed for a couple years at MOST?!" Achilles rubbed his throat and took a long quaff of ale as his voice squeaked again. It was like going through puberty again!

"Are you alright, Achilles?" Lucius asked as he finished off his second plate of the second course.

"Yeah, I think so."

Mordred gave Merlin a stern look, but Merlin gave his very convincing innocent look to his father in return. Mordred turned back to Achilles and said, "I doubt the trade deal with only last a couple years. Since Fantasmia has no Douglas Pine forests left, even if we began planting trees again, it will take at least fifty years before a tree is of sufficient age to harvest its wood for wand-making. This will definitely be a long-term trade agreement between our two countries, though the amount of wood asked for in the trade will probably vary from year to year based on demand."

"Mordred, are you feeling okay?" asked Achilles. Mordred's face had taken on a lighter and lighter hue as he spoke until his face now looked pale and wan.

"I feel fine. Why?"

"You just look a bit PALE THAT'S...CAW, CAW, CAW!"

Achilles's eyes widened. Everyone at the table watched as Achilles's face slowly morphed from having a nose and mouth, to having a long, yellow beak! Merlin couldn't contain his laughter anymore, though.

"Hahahahahaha! HAHAHA, HAHA-HON-KEY, HON-KEY! RIB-BIT, CROAK, RIB-BIT! SQUEAK, SQUEAK, SQUEAK, SQUEAK, SQUEAK!"

All the sounds coming out of his mouth, just made Merlin laugh harder. Achilles and/or his father must have spiked his own drink! Then, when he saw his father's face and hair turn a disgusting puke-green, he practically doubled over in laughter! Mordred summoned a mirror to see just what his son had done to him, and couldn't help smirking and chuckling himself at how horrid he looked with pasty green skin and hair! Achilles was already in a similar state as his son, holding his stomach as he laughed and laughed, well, cawed and cawed!

Before long, the rest of the table soon joined in, and the whole table spent several minutes chortling with glee.

"Well, Mordred," said Lucius, giving another laugh and wiping his eyes, "your son seems to have picked up your and Achilles's penchant for mischief-making!"

"CAW, CAW, CAW!" agreed Achilles with a violent nod of his head, his eyes sparkling with amusement.

"Yes, well, Achilles figured Merlin would try something on us, so he convinced me to put a potion in his drink tonight. Looks like the prank's on all three of us!" Turning to Merlin, he patted his son on the back with pride and said, "Those were ingenious potions, Son. I'm proud of you!"

The rest of the table watched as Mordred's face and hair slowly turned from its sickly green color to a bright fuchsia, and Achilles's face morphed again from a bird's beak to a pig's snout! Merlin doubled over with laughter again, continuing to make multiple animal noises as he laughed. "OINK, OINK, OINK, SNOOOOOORT! MOOOOOOO-HOO-HOO-HOO! CHIRP, CHIRP, CHIRP, TWEET, TWEET!"

"Well," Mordred finally said as the third course was being served, and he and Achilles had gone through two more changes: red and orange plaid, then pink polka-dots, and an alligator nose and an elephant trunk, respectively. "If this keeps up, we'll be laughing too hard to eat the rest of this marvelous dinner our kitchen staff has prepared."

Mordred had placed his black wand on the table near his silverware when he had sat down to dinner. It had a brilliant white diamond at its tip. "Restituo!" he said, waving his wand in a pattern over Achilles, himself, and then his son.

"Phew!" Achilles said, running his hands over his restored face. "Thanks, Mor! I was afraid I'd be changing into all sorts of animals all night long!"

Igraine gave a cute little giggle, and Achilles gave her a wide smile. "I bet you liked all those animal faces, didn't you, Igraine?"

Igraine nodded her head and gave Achilles a shy smile.

"Well, it was all worth it, then," said Merlin, turning to his cousin and running his hand over Igraine's shiny blond hair. His little cousin hadn't smiled much since her father was killed, and he made it his quest every day to try and coax a smile or a laugh out of her.

"I don't know about the rest of you, but I say it's time for dessert!" said Mordred, waving his hand for the servants to clear the plates so that dessert could be served.

Lucius stifled a sigh as he still felt rather hungry. He was used to much larger meals with a minimum of six courses. Perhaps he could find a snack later on.
15423121.title: Mischievous Merlin plays a prank at dinner.

choices: Lucius has a lonely future but becomes a great battle general for Mountania.
Lucius has a future filled with intrigue and love.
15423122.content:
Lucius looked around in awe at the White Castle as Mordred led everyone down several hallways to the dining hall. The large, white stone blocks were polished and shone brilliantly as numerous torches lit the way along the corridors. Portraits of Mordred's family lined one of the hallways. Several ancestors appeared stern and almost disapproving, but most appeared friendly with smiles or mischievous smirks on their faces. Lucius had to do a double-take at one of the more recent portraits. He could have sworn he saw the man in portrait wink at him! Lucius peered closer at the nameplate underneath.

"Hmm, Draxon Osric Canticum," Lucius muttered to himself. He looked back up at the slightly pudgy wizard with dirty blond hair and quickly took a step back, his eyes wide. It wasn't his imagination: the portrait winked at him again!

"M-mordred!" Lucius hissed.

Mordred quickly came over to Lucius's side, a concerned look on his face. "Are you alright, Lucius?"

"That...that portrait winked at me! TWICE!"

Mordred looked at the portrait and began laughing. "Lucius, that's just Grandfather Draxon! He magicked his portrait before he died so that his likeness would do something different for everyone. See what it does for me."

Mordred stepped close, and the portrait raised a hand and waved at him.

"Do any of the other portraits move?" asked Lucius suspiciously.

Mordred laughed. "A few do, but it's nothing to worry about."

Lucius shook his head. Despite the obvious grandeur of this Castle, which reminded him with a pang in his heart of his former home in Ferramount, Lucius was sure he'd be reminded at every turn that this was a palace inhabited by wizards and magic. Nothing would be as it seemed here, he was sure.

When they got to the dining hall, everyone began to gather around their usual chairs at the main table. Mordred was at the head with Merlin and Viviane on his left and right, respectively. Achilles was next to Viviane, Igraine next to Merlin, and Morgaine at the foot of the table. Lucius, however, hung back, uncertain where exactly he was supposed to sit, until little Igraine walked slowly up to him. She hesitantly held out an arm to him, and Lucius squatted down and grasped her hand gently in his.

"Would you...sit next to me, Uh...Uncle Lu-siss?" she said quietly.

Lucius gulped and smiled kindly at her. While he'd always loved being around children, he'd never had one take a liking to him so quickly. "I would love to, if...." He looked up to see everyone else looking at them. "...If it's alright with everyone else."

Morgaine smiled at him, making the breath catch in his throat. "I usually sit at the foot of the table opposite my brother, but how about you sit at the foot of the table, instead, and that way you can sit between Igraine and me."

Lucius cleared his throat, then stood up and smiled crookedly. "Sitting between two lovely ladies? How could I refuse?"

Achilles laughed as everyone took their seats at the table. "There's the charming brother I know and love! How can any Mountanian resist the attentions of a woman, even one as small and beautiful as Igraine?" Achilles winked at the girl across the table, and she giggled at his antics.

Lucius rolled his eyes at his brother as servants came and began placing plates filled with salad and bowls of soup on the table in front of everyone, as well as filling goblets with ale, wine, or lemonade. Lucius eagerly dug into this first course of the meal, anxious to fill his empty, growling stomach. The meals they had eaten on their three-day trip from Laceton had been hasty and hardly filling, so Lucius reveled in the delicious food provided by his wizardly friends.

The conversation during the several course meal flowed freely and was filled with talk of the upcoming trade agreement between Mountania and Fantasmia, catching everyone up on happenings in their families, and the current political climates of Mountania and Fatlantis, with plenty of jokes and laughing to make the entire affair quite pleasant and enjoyable.

Lucius enjoyed eating several plates of each course, moaning in delight when a particularly delectable dish met his tongue. He began to get a bit uncomfortable, however, when he noticed the beautiful lady on his left eying his hands as he ate. When he grabbed his goblet and slowly brought it to his lips, her eyes followed his hand's movement. Wondering if his hands were dirty or bleeding or something, he surreptitiously put them in his lap, wiped them with his napkin, and subtly looked them over. They seemed perfectly normal to him. However, when he resumed eating, Morgaine was watching his hands again, with a longing look in her eyes.

Eventually, Lucius was so discomfited, he cleared his throat and asked her softly, "Lady Morgaine,...is there something wrong with my hands?"

Morgaine shook her head as if coming out of a daze and raised her wide eyes to his face. She brought her hand to her throat. "I'm...so sorry, Prince Lucius. Was I staring at your hands?"

"Yes. Did you not realize?"

Morgaine's cheeks turned pink. "I didn't. Forgive me."

"Mama," said Igraine softly. "Uncle Lu-siss has big hands."

Morgaine sighed, and Lucius turned to the young girl, only now realizing that Igraine had also been looking at his hands.

"Yes, he does, Sweetheart, but we mustn't--"

"Morgaine, Igraine, not this again!" sighed Mordred. Despite the low tone of their conversation at the foot of the table, everyone else at the table had overheard.

"I'm sorry, but can someone tell me what this is all about?" Lucius asked.

Mordred and Morgaine had a silent conversation with their eyes, and then Morgaine turned back to Lucius. "It all began with our maternal grandmother," Morgaine explained. "She was a Valleyan. She had a certain degree of innate gypsy magic in her that initially attracted our grandfather. She was quite gifted at reading palms and Seeing hints of a person's future. Her magic seemed to have skipped a generation with our mother, but I inherited some of her Seer's abilities, as has Igraine. Whenever we are introduced to a person for the first time, it's as if our natures clamor for us to have a look at their palms and read their future."

"Hey, yeah! I forgot about that!" said Achilles. "You did the same thing to me when we were kids. Freaked me out a bit, but it was cool to have you tell me about my future. I still remember this one line you said: "Achilles, you are very fortunate to have no branches off your love line. You will love once and completely your whole life, and that love will be wholly returned to you." And let me tell you, as soon as I met Livia, it was the truth! I loved her from the beginning, and I always will!"

"Ah, but I wasn't completely accurate, as I remember," Morgaine said with a smile. "I also predicted you'd have three children by the time you were 30. You only have two."

"Well," Achilles said with a sparkle in his eyes, "I think Livia is actually expecting our third; we just have yet to confirm it."

"Really? That's wonderful! Congratulations, my friend," said Mordred.

Everyone raised their goblet at the news of Achilles's possible impending child. Then, Igraine said, "Uncle Lu-siss? May I...read your palm?"

Lucius put his goblet down and looked at Achilles, uncertain. Achilles shook his head and chuckled. "Go ahead, Lu. Indulge the girl. It doesn't hurt, I swear it!"

"No, it doesn't hurt," said Morgaine, "but an accurate reading reveals both the highs and the lows, the good and the bad in one's future."

Lucius frowned. "So, you're saying that everything in my future you can tell from merely looking at the lines on my palms? Forgive me if I don't quite buy that."

Morgaine shook her head. "Not everything. Only hints, shadows, possibilities. Our hands change as we grow older. Our past and our present shapes the lines on our palms, and so our futures change as we experience life. For example, my own palms have changed since Lancelot died. No one anticipated that he would die long before his time. There is now a distinct break in my love line that wasn't there before, indicating that while my previous love has passed on, I may yet experience love in the future."

When Lucius hesitated, Achilles said, "Ah, come on, bro! Give it a try! You don't wanna break a young girl's heart, now, do you?"

Lucius looked into Igraine's lovely dark blue eyes--the same as her mother's--and sighed, knowing he would give in. Yet, still sensing his reluctance, Morgaine said, "If it would be more comfortable for you, and since Igraine is still pretty new at this, how about she read your right hand, while I read your left? In general, the two hands reveal the same information for a person, and you can be more confident of your reading, as two people are telling it to you independently. Would that be alright?"

Lucius looked at the eager faces of everyone at the table and sighed. Despite feeling a bit boxed in, he figured it really wouldn't hurt. "Alright," he said with a nod.
15423122.title: Morgaine is seated next to Lucius, and she give...

choices: Chapter continues...
154231222.content:
*Author's note: The palm reading that takes place in this chapter may not necessarily follow typical understandings of palm lines and is not meant to be completely accurate by true palmistry readings of today. I have modified it to suit my own purposes in the chapter.*

"Oh, goody!" said Igraine, as she eagerly reached for Lucius's right hand.

Morgaine laughed at her daughter's excitement. It was so good to see Igraine acting more like her beloved, precocious little girl, instead of the wary, somber reflection of the person she usually was. Morgaine reached for Lucius's left hand and gasped as a jolt of energy went through her body. This man was different, she could already sense that. But to experience THIS kind of connection....

Lucius squirmed in his seat a bit as Igraine's little fingers running over his palm felt a bit ticklish. Igraine was peering very closely at his hand, making him feel a bit self-conscious. No one had paid particular attention to his hands in a long time.

"I can never get over how different the hands are of you Mountanian royalty," said Morgaine softly. "I have read the palms of the entire royal family of Fatlantis and Fantasmia, and their hands are all soft and chubby and smooth. But Mountanian hands are rough with calluses and nicked and scarred."

"Well, what do you expect, Sweetheart," said Achilles, "when we Mountanians are always hard at work? We wield swords, guns, hammers, bellows, picks, axes, saws, any manner of tool or weapon, you name it! Even though we're royalty, we work and work-out just as hard as the rest of our people, if not harder!"

"Wow!" said Igraine, running a finger along one of the lines on Lucius's hand. "Your life line is very long, Uncle Lu-siss!"

Morgaine chuckled. "Indeed it is! I estimate you'll live well into your nineties, your highness!"

"Wow! Ninety!" said Achilles. He grinned at his brother. "I'm only expected to live into my eighties! Way to go, bro!"

Lucius squirmed in his seat again, uncertain how to answer. He was surprised to hear he might outlive his younger brother. He looked down at his large belly, sitting heavily on his thighs, contentedly full from their scrumptious dinner. How could someone as overweight as he live such a long life?

"Pppfffft!" said Mordred in dismissal. "Ninety is nothing! We wizards typically live past one hundred!"

"Except you!" Achilles teased. "I remember when Morgaine read your palm, Mor! You'll live no longer that I will!"

As the two friends continued bantering back and forth, Igraine wrinkled her brow and said, "Mama, I don't understand."

"Understand what, Darling?"

"Lu-siss's love line, Mama. It's...hard to follow."

"Ah. That's because there's a long break in it. See where it starts right below his index finger? There is a very short line there."

"Oh, I see that," said Igraine, moving her fingers lightly over Lucius's palm. He squirmed again as the gentle sensation tickled. He didn't know how much more of this he could withstand without rubbing his hands furiously on his pants to override the tickling feeling!

"Now," Morgaine continued, "move across his palm to just under his ring finger. The line starts up again and continues clear across to the end of his palm, marking quite deeply, with several branches."

"Ooooooh!" Igraine then bit her lip as she kept running a finger over the stretch of palm that had no love line. She looked up into Lucius's face, and Lucius was concerned to see tears in the girl's eyes.

"Igraine?" he asked softly.

Lucius was completely surprised when Igraine dropped his hand, got out of her seat, and scrambled up into his lap. She put her arms around his neck and held onto him in a tight hug. Lucius looked at Morgaine with wide eyes, but Morgaine seemed just as astonished at her daughter's behavior. Not knowing what else to do, Lucius put his arms around the little girl and held her close.

"I'm so sorry, Uncle Lu-siss," Igraine said quietly into his shoulder. "No one should live without love!"

Lucius gulped and closed his eyes, putting his cheek down on Igraine's soft, blond hair. He relished in the comfort her warm little body gave him. This seven-year-old girl was one of the few who had given him comfort over the many years since Danielle's death. Everyone seemed so quick to blame him for her death, for his misdeeds, and no one acknowledged that he felt her loss and the loss of their unborn child. He'd not really been allowed to grieve, and the pain of their loss hit him anew as Igraine poured out her compassion for him by holding him close.

He let a few tears escape his eyes in remembrance of his teenage love and the child that had never been.
154231222.title: Lucius has a future filled with intrigue and love.

choices: The next day, Achilles and Lucius arrive in Ferramount.
Curious about the future, Morgaine peers into her crystal ball.
1542312221.content:
The rest of the table was silent as they watched Igraine give Lucius a comforting hug. All present except Merlin knew of Lucius's past. Mordred and Achilles were both acutely aware that Lucius had kept to himself for the past twenty years, out of fear of losing someone else that he was close to, of losing his head and doing something else to dishonor his family. Achilles knew that Lucius kept himself so tightly in control (with the exception of his eating--his one vice), that Lucius was almost more honorable than anyone in his family, including himself! But to hear it so baldly stated that Lucius had not dared to love anyone since Danielle.... Achilles's heart ached for his brother, and it made him more determined to try and find someone with whom Lucius could learn to love again. Lucius was too good a man to live the rest of his life alone and lonely.

Morgaine, meanwhile, was utterly touched. Her daughter rarely took to strangers, but from the moment Lucius had stepped from the carriage, Igraine had taken an instant liking to him. Morgaine could easily see why. He had an unassuming, friendly air about him, with just enough wariness and caution to pique a woman's interest. He obviously enjoyed his food, but Morgaine didn't mind a belly on a man, as it proclaimed he enjoyed overindulging. Morgaine knew that when a man had a passion for food, he often had passions for...other things. Combine that with his tall, muscular figure, his neat brown hair and deep brown eyes, and the strong, rugged looks that proclaimed him a Mountanian warrior, and Morgaine had felt her heart flutter when she first saw him. That had surprised her, for it was still soon for her to be showing an interest in a man when her husband had been gone for only three months. However, the jolt she had felt when she had touched his hand, plus the interesting configuration of his love line, had her looking at him in wonder. Could she find love again with this lonely man, whom her daughter had already formed a bond with so quickly?

Achilles cleared his throat and said, "So, Morgaine, what can you deduce about my brother's love life, hmm?"

"Well, the resumption of the line indicates he'll find love again, and I'd wager it will be within the coming year. It branches off three different times, indicating he'll love three different women. Be warned, though, your highness: I See ambition and betrayal with one of your loves. Be careful whom you fall in love with. However, on a happy note, the third time you experience love, it will be completely and for the rest of your life."

"Wow, intriguing!” said Achilles. “You hear that, bro? You'll fall in love three times before you find the right woman to settle down with!"

"I heard, Achilles," Lucius said softly. He couldn't really believe it. He'd kept himself from women for so long, and hearing he'd fall in love again, no less than three times in the next year, seemed absurd. He especially didn't like that one woman would betray him. Lucius snorted. As if he'd let a woman close enough to him for that to happen! Still, a small part of him longed for what Morgaine said, that he'd find his...soulmate within a year.

Igraine suddenly pulled away from him and looked up in his face with a big smile. "And you wanna know the best part, Uncle Lu-siss?"

Lucius smiled and ran a hand over Igraine's long blond hair. "What?"

"You're gonna be a Papa!"

Lucius swallowed hard. Children. If the impossible happened, and he found love, would he then finally experience the joy of fatherhood, as well? "Oh, will I?" he tried to say as nonchalantly as he could.

Igraine nodded her eagerly, her grin widening. "Yep! And you'll have lots!"

"May I see your hand again, Lucius?" Morgaine asked him.

Lucius dumbly extended his left hand to her again, and Morgaine inspected it closely. Her eyes widened with a gasp. "It's true! I didn't see that before!"

"See what before?" Achilles asked.

Morgaine chuckled. "Your brother will be...er...quite prolific."

"Oh, yeah?" Achilles said with a grin.

Lucius's face turned red.

"I see at least five children, if not more. There are so many little lines underneath his little finger, the exact number is hard to count."

Five children?! Lucius's eyes were wide. He could only hope to be so blessed so late in his life!

Morgaine meanwhile put a hand to her belly. If Lucius were to be her future intended...she would be the one bearing him those five or more children! Morgaine didn't have an easy time carrying Igraine and did not truly relish carrying anymore. However,.... Her cheeks flushed, and she reached for her goblet of wine to wet her parched throat. The thought of what would go into making all those children had warmth blooming in her belly.

"Can I come and play with your babies, Uncle Lu-siss?" asked Igraine. "I like babies."

Lucius gave a nervous chuckle. "Of course! I'm sure, when...if the time comes, I...we...er...could use all the help we can get."

Igraine gave Lucius another quick hug and then scrambled down from his lap to go sit in her chair.

"Well," said Mordred after a pause, wiping the remains of his chocolate cake from his lips, "let's withdraw to the drawing room for the evening, shall we? Lucius, I'm looking forward to playing a game of chess with you. Achilles, here, hadn't presented much of a challenge to me recently, and I hear you're quite the player."

"Hey!" said Achilles.

Lucius chuckled as everyone rose from their seats. "I'd be delighted," he said. Anything to get his mind off the rather interesting palm reading he just received!
1542312221.title: Chapter continues...

choices: their brother, King Leviathan, who was waiting for them.
their father, King Hercules, who was holding court.
15423122211.content:
Lucius rubbed his sweaty palms on his trousers for the fifth time in so many minutes. He hadn't been back to Mountania or Ferramount for three years, not since the last time he had been commissioned to broker a trade deal between his brother King Leviathan and King David of Fatlantis. While Lucius missed his home with all his heart and relished any opportunity to see his beloved country and the palace he grew up in,...his relationships with his father Hercules and his brother Levi were still very strained. Despite more than twenty years having gone by since Danielle's death and his appointment as Lord of Laceton, his father had yet to truly forgive him for the disgrace he had brought to the royal family.

Leviathan was another matter. Lucius and Leviathan had always had an intense brotherly rivalry, being only two years apart in age. They were always pitted against each other in contests, competitions, races, school studies. Levi took every defeat to heart and became that much more earnest to best his older and, when they were children, slightly taller and stronger brother. It didn't help that their personalities were so different. Levi relished attention and being around people. He was a natural-born leader, and people were easily drawn into his sphere of influence. He was forever going on hunts with the sons of most of Mountania's nobility, hiking and camping and practicing their fighting and survival skills together in the mountainous highlands. Lucius, however, preferred a smaller circle of friends and enjoyed more quiet pursuits, such as reading and writing. He enjoyed architecture, sculpture, and music. Despite his obvious love of food, he also trained rigorously and religiously...just never to the point of obsession that Levi was wont to at times.

Lucius sighed as he saw the magnificent castle and city of Ferramount looming in the distance outside of his carriage window. Hercules had always favored Levi's dominant personality, but because Lucius was his firstborn, Hercules pushed him that much harder to try and measure up to Levi's obvious worth as kingly material. Lucius never seemed to measure up, though, no matter how hard he tried to please their father. Lucius couldn't help but wonder if Hercules was glad when the mess with Danielle came to light, allowing Hercules to change the line of succession and make his more favored son his primary heir.

Levi never treated Lucius the same after that, even though Lucius had been only sixteen and Levi fourteen at the time. Of course, Levi had always been closest to their father and idolized him. While Lucius and Levi had never quite gotten along, as brothers were wont to do, Lucius had always thought there was a brotherly love between them, as well. Any love that might have existed between them seemed to have disappeared after Lucius was deposed. If Levi had merely been aping their father's opinion of Lucius, surely such feelings would have decreased over time. However, Levi was just as unforgiving and barely tolerant of Lucius's presence as their father, no matter how well Lucius had kept himself out of trouble or how well he performed his duties to his country and family as emissary in Laceton.

Lucius sighed again and rubbed his wet palms one more time on his pants in his nervousness. When he had received Reggie's letter, he had been so thrilled to have a chance to get out of Laceton for a while that he had temporarily forgotten the type of welcome he was sure to receive in Ferramount. Now, he just wanted to get this trade deal presented and over with so that he could deal with his brother and father as little as possible. Even with Achilles' mediatory and joking presence to serve as a buffer, Lucius doubted Levi would be that much more amenable to suffering Lucius's presence longer than a few hours at most.

"Bro, calm down," said Achilles with a shake of his head. He had watched Lucius's nervous fidgeting for the past fifteen miles and was saddened to see his normally easy-going brother so on edge. "It's only Levi! I thought you were looking forward to being home again!"

"I am!" Lucius said hoarsely. "It's just...all these memories.... And it's not 'only Levi,' as you say. You know how both he and Father still regard me. I can never do right in either of their eyes. The best I can do is just try and make the best negotiation for Reggie and appeal to Levi's sense of trade and fair-play."

Achilles sighed as Lucius looked out the window again, gulped, and rubbed his hands one more time on his thighs. Achilles didn't know himself why Levi and their father were still so harsh with Lucius. Achilles got along well with everyone; he just couldn't understand how one little misdeed that happened when Lucius was a stupid teenager should still be ruining relationships in their family twenty years later! Lucius was a great guy--the epitome of Mountanian strength, courage, and loyalty. How could their father and Levi not see that?

"Well, you're not here all by yourself," Achilles said. "Remember that I'm here to help and run any interference for you, okay?"

Lucius chuckled. "I don't need you to fight my battles for me, Achilles."

"I know you don't, but what could it hurt to have another fighter in your corner?"

Lucius gave his younger brother a small smile. "Thanks, Achilles."

Achilles grinned and leaned over to punch his brother in the shoulder. "Anytime, Lu!"

Lucius tried desperately to not let his nerves get the best of him, but when the carriage drove over the massive moat that surrounded the enormous palace of Ferramount, Lucius couldn't help a hard gulp. As the carriage drove past a large patch of green grass, he watched two teenaged boys viciously practice their sword-fighting. They had quite an audience watching, and Lucius wondered with the boys' sandy blond hair and tall statures if they were Levi's oldest two sons, Cassius and Gladius. Lucius had barely met the boys, but he knew that Levi was quite proud of his three sons and that they were shaping up to be good, strong Mountanian warriors.

When the carriage parked in front of a large set of heavy, wooden doors, Lucius closed his eyes and took a deep breath. Achilles was right. He could do this. He HAD to do this!

Achilles leaped out of the carriage, and Lucius followed him.

"Hey, Cygnus!" said Achilles, slapping a brown-haired manservant on the shoulder. "How have you been?"

Cygnus was the palace chamberlain. When the royal guards on the wall surrounding the city spied a carriage marked with the royal seal, they had sent a messenger to the palace to inform them a royal visitor would be arriving shortly, and therefore Cygnus had been patiently waiting for them outside the royal palace.

"I have been very well, your royal highness," the man said with a small bow and a smile. Cygnus's smile faded and his eyes widened when he spied Lucius, but he bowed again. "A...pleasure to see you again, as well, your royal highness."

"Hello, Cygnus," said Lucius kindly.

"I take it Levi is waiting for us," Achilles said.

Cygnus nodded, then waved to several servant boys who had been waiting behind him to begin taking the princes's luggage off the carriage. "Yes, he's waiting for you in the throne-room, your highness."

"Don't worry about the luggage, boys," said Lucius, "Achilles and I can take care of it all ourselves."

Achilles sighed and swung an arm around Lucius's shoulders. "You forget you're in Ferramount, Bro. Let the boys do their work. How else are they gonna learn and build muscle?"

"Sorry," said Lucius with a bit of a blush as Achilles led him into the palace, following Cygnus. "I guess I'm just too used to being in Laceton, with so few servants around to take care of everything for me."

Lucius took a deep breath and sighed in delight as they entered the large foyer of the immense stone and granite castle of Ferramount. The numerous Corinthian and round columns, wide sweeping staircases, and ornate balustrades had lines of lovely colors running all through them as they had been hewn and carved and polished out of numerous different native granite mountains--a testament to the diversity yet unity of Mountania's people and land. THIS was what Lucius had missed living in the lowlands and prairies of Fatlantis for so long.

Achilles and he wandered up one of the long, sloping staircases to the second level and walked a ways down a wide hallway before coming to another set of tall, enormous wooden doors: the throne-room.

Suddenly, Lucius's nerves all came back. Sweat began beading on his forehead, and he wiped his now-sweaty palms again on his trouser legs.

"Hey, Lu," said Achilles softly. "It'll be alright. Trust me!"

Lucius took a deep breath and nodded before the two of them knocked on the doors. A pair of strong guards opened the doors and bowed before the two princes. Lucius and Achilles walked up to the doorway, then bowed before...
15423122211.title: The next day, Achilles and Lucius arrive in Fer...

choices: Lucius and Achilles train for their competitions tomorrow.
Lucius meets Levi's sons at dinner.
154231222111.content:
Lucius and Achilles bowed before their brother, King Leviathan, who sat upon a beautiful, ornately carved granite throne at the other end of the throne-room.

“Achilles,” said Levi across the room, “how many times have I told you to not stand on ceremony?”

Achilles straightened back up and grinned at his brother as he walked quickly down the red runner that ran from the throne-room doors to his brother's throne. “Sorry, Levi. I felt such a dignified room deserved that I showed you the proper respect!”

Levi chuckled, got down from his throne, and engulfed his younger brother in a quick, tight hug.

Lucius, meanwhile, began a meandering pace towards his brothers.

Levi pulled back and tugged on Achilles's long red pony-tail. “Still have this thing, huh?”

Achilles grinned. “You know how badly it curls when it's short. Besides, Livia thinks it makes me look dashing.”

Levi chuckled again, but the gaiety on his face dissolved when Lucius came into view behind Achilles. “You,” he said simply.

Lucius took a deep breath and nodded his head. “Hello, Levi. You're looking well.”

Levi sneered. “You are looking fatter than ever.”

“Hey, take it easy, Levi,” said Achilles.

Levi spared Achilles a glance, then focused back on Lucius. “Why are you here? I have not summoned you.”

Lucius presented a scroll with the Fantasmian royal seal on it to his brother. “I'm here by request of King Reginald of Fantasmia. He asked me to personally oversee a possible trade negotiation between his country and ours.”

Levi took the proffered scroll and read the brief missive. “Douglas Pine wood? For wand-crafting?”

“Yes. Apparently, Douglas Pine wands are all the rage in Fantasmia these days.”

“So, this is just a fad? You honestly want me to negotiate a trade for a commodity that will only be needed for a short period of time?”

“Of course not. When Achilles and I journeyed here, we stopped briefly at the White Castle, and Mordred and Morgaine believe that since Fantasmia has no Douglas Pine forests left, they will always have a need for a steady supply of this wood from Mountania.”

Leviathan went back up to sit on his throne and ponder through this negotiation. “And what would they give in return?”

“Well, King Reginald is willing to pay mightily for the wood, in upwards of a hundred gold sovereigns per board-foot.” Lucius held back that Reggie was willing to pay twice that amount.

Levi whistled. “That's quite a lot of gold for a mere board-foot of wood. They must be desperate. However, with our own wealth, we have little need for more gold.”

Lucius nodded. He had already thought of that. “Yes, therefore, I was thinking a trade for one of their commodities would be better.”

“Which commodity? There is little we need from Fantasmia.”

“Oh? Did you know that one of Fantasmia's premiere sorcerers has developed a potion to combat mining sickness?”

Mountania's miners had been dying from mining sickness for as long as anyone could remember. Everyone knew it was a dangerous profession, but the mining industry was a strong staple of Mountanian life, and mining families had grown used to the fact that their loved ones would lead short lives.

Both Levi's and Achilles's eyes widened. “Really?” asked Achilles. “I hadn't heard that!”

“Apparently the king of Lucia commissioned the sorcerer to find a cure for the sickness their miners were succumbing to. The sorcerer discovered the sickness was caused by a particular mineral present in the dust the miners breathed in during their excavation. The sorcerer was able to develop a potion to isolate this mineral in the miners' blood and expunge it from their bodies, allowing them to heal and return to work.”

Levi leaned forward excitedly. “Such a cure would be a great boon to our people!”

“Yes. In fact, I have already made inquiries about the potion. Apparently, the contaminant in the Lucian rock is the same as what we have here in Mountania that makes our own miners sick. The curative potion is rather simple to make, and I bet if we asked the Valleyans or Mordred, they would be more than willing to make it for us.”

“I don't understand. Why have the Valleyans or Mordred make the potion? Why not trade the Douglas Pine wood for the potion from Fantasmia?”

“Because the potion is not effective for longer than twelve hours after brewing. We would need to make the potion here in Mountania for our people to take. What we need to trade the Douglas Pine wood for would be the key ingredient in the potion: feathered ferns.”

Leviathan sighed. “It would figure that the main ingredient would be a plant that cannot grow in the arid highlands of Mountania.” Indeed, feathered ferns only grew along the humid southern coastline of Fantasmia.

“So,” continued Levi, “you propose we trade our prevalent Douglas Pine wood for Fantasmia's feathered ferns. Interesting and lucrative. I must admit, Lucius, you surprise me.”

Lucius shrugged. “I take my responsibilities seriously.” Leviathan had no idea how dedicated Lucius was to his role as emissary. Lucius gathered any and all information he could about the goings on of Mountania, Fatlantis, Fantasmia, Lucia, Obesitan, and any other country that Mountania did or could have dealings with. He was forever having messengers come and go from his manor house in Laceton, bringing him books or scrolls. He was always reading and making notes, coming up with ideas of possible trade deals between Mountanian, Fatlantis, and their surrounding neighbors.

“How much wood would Fantasmia need every year?” Levi asked.

“Well, the exact amount will vary from year to year based on demand, but right now, they require a minimum of ten thousand board-feet of wood.”

“That's a lot of wood they are asking for! And while Mountania is covered in Douglas Pine forests, I am not sure we can sustain such a large demand over the next ten or so years without significant depletion.”

“I agree, which is why I would like to bring Epimetheus into these negotiations. He knows best how much wood can be cut from our forests and new trees planted and re-grown to keep the tree-levels stable.”

Levi's eyes widened slightly in surprise. “Yes, that would be a good idea. He and the Valleyans will all be here tomorrow for my annual birthday celebration, and we could speak to him about this matter then.” Levi then gave a small smirk. “You and Achilles shall both attend, of course. It wouldn't do for members of my family to be present at the castle and not attend such a grand event.”

Lucius gulped. He would have to stay in Ferramount for at least a couple more days, now, and he would have to attend his brother's annual birthday gala. How could he have forgotten the date of Levi's birthday? Levi always held a huge party to honor the occasion, and every courtier and noble family attended the large soiree.

“Hey, I forgot tomorrow was your birthday, Bro,” said Achilles with a smile. “It's been a long time since I've been to one of your birthday parties. Do you still hold a series of competitions and offer roast Mountain goat at dinner?”

Levi laughed. “Of course! In fact, Cassius and Gladius came in third and fourth place year in the decathlon last year. I'm hoping they will be even better this year!”

“It's been a long time since I've been in a competition.” Achilles flexed his impressive arm muscles and grinned at his brother. “Think there's a spot for me in the arm-wrestling competition?”

Levi grinned back. “Oh, I think we can make room. Though I have to warn you: I have been the winner of that competition for the past ten years.”

“Well, then, I'll have to make sure and give you a decent run for your money. Hey, Lu! Which competition do you think you'd want to enter?”

Lucius sighed as Levi's smile faded. Just like that, the civility of the trade negotiations was gone. “We don't have an eating competition,” Levi sneered. “If we did, I'm sure you'd be the winner, Lucius.”

Lucius's patience was beginning to stretch thin. “Look, Levi, I do more than eat. I train every day, I'll have you know!”

“Oh? You could have fooled me. Seems the only training you get is lifting a fork to your mouth.”

“Come on, Levi,” said Achilles. “Look at Lucius's arms. You can't maintain that kind of musculature by sitting around doing nothing.”

Levi eyed his brother up and down. “All I see is a fat gut and flabby arms and legs couched in blubber.”

Lucius narrowed his eyes. “Look, Levi,” he said softly. “I don't care what you see. I don't have to prove myself to you.”

“Don't you? You want to keep your beloved post in Laceton? Then, I dare you to compete in one of the competitions tomorrow. In fact, I dare you to compete in the other competition I have always won: weight-lifting. Let's see just what those flabby arms and legs of yours can do.”

Lucius clenched his fists and grit his teeth. “Fine! If that's what you want, I'll show you I'm not useless weakling!”

“I look forward to it! Cygnus!”

The chamberlain scurried forward and bowed. “My liege?”

“Show my brothers to their quarters.”

“Yes, my lord! Follow me, your highnesses.”

"Your rooms, your royal highnesses," said Cygnus with a bow, indicating two large doors situated next to each other in the family wing of the Mountanian royal palace. "Dinner will be served at six."

"Thanks, Cygnus!" said Achilles with a smile and a pat on the servant's back.

As Cygnus left down the long, stone hallway, Achilles turned back to his oldest brother. "So, which room do you want, Lu?"

Lucius rolled his eyes. "It doesn't matter, Achilles. I'll just take this one on the right, though if I find your luggage in it, I'll trade you."

Personally, even though I know I shouldn't pick favorites between my brothers, I'm rooting for you to win against him in that weight-lifting contest tomorrow. He had no idea how strong his kingly brother was these days, but he wanted to give himself as much of a work-out as he could today to make sure he even had a chance at beating Levi. So, Lucius hurried down the hallways and stairs to a large Olympic-sized track outside the back of the palace that the royal family used for running and training. Situated in the middle of the large, five-mile track was an enormous grassy area with sections carved out for different pursuits: high jump, long jump, pole vault, discus, and shot put; a matted and tiled section for martial arts or wrestling practice; an area with targets and numerous bows and arrows for archery; another area with guns, pistols, and gun targets; and lastly, in the very middle, was a bricked area filled with weights and weight-lifting benches, suspended bars for chin-ups, as well as mats for crunches, sit-ups, and jump roping.

It was to this middle section that Lucius headed, shedding his tunic in deference to the heat of the day. Despite being somewhat comfortable in his skin, he didn't relish the thought of anyone spying him shirtless, with his large belly on display.

As Lucius began a rigorous routine, challenging the bulging muscles of his arms and legs with thousands of pounds of weight on the barbells and hand weights, he didn't realize that nobles from all over Mountania and dignitaries from some surrounding countries were beginning to arrive at the palace for tomorrow's celebration of Leviathan's birthday. While most of the arriving guests had already done most of their training and preparation for tomorrow's games at home and merely wanted a good night's sleep, a few ventured down to train with Achilles in the palace weight room.

"It couldn't be,...could it?" the Duke murmured to himself. He stroked a thumb across his goatee'd chin in consideration.

Of course, everyone knew the rumors and speculation surrounding the change in succession and Lucius's subsequent posting to Laceton in Fatlantis. Jupiter wondered at Lucius's unusual presence back here in Ferramount and could only figure it had to do with the king's birthday gala tomorrow,...though Lucius had never attended one before. Regardless, Jupiter might be able to use Lucius's presence here to his advantage.

An evil smile slowly curved the Duke's dark mustachioed face.

A knock on his open door followed by a "Father, are you ready for dinner?" only made Jupiter's smile widen.

"Almost, my dear," he said to his daughter, beckoning her to come join him by the window.

Juno was the Duke's only child and, at 22 years old, was still unmarried. However, Jupiter had been waiting for the right man to marry off his pride and joy. Juno's mother had died when Juno was five, giving birth to her younger brother, who also didn't survive the birth. Jupiter had had no desire to marry again, and so had poured all his devotion and affection on his daughter. Being one of the wealthiest noblemen in Mountania and being possessed of a rather ambitious and cunning nature, which he had passed down to Juno, Jupiter wasn't about to marry off his daughter to just anyone, especially since Jupiter planned on granting his Dukedom to the first son that would come from his daughter's union.

Not that Juno didn't attract suitors, because she did--in droves! Juno was tall for a woman, at nearly six feet in height, and possessed a lithe, athletic figure that was rounded in just the right places. She had silky black hair that fell in a long sheet down to her bottom, an oval face with flawless, creamy skin and high cheekbones, and bright, almond-shaped green eyes. She was just as choosy as her father when considering a potential husband: she only wanted the best and wealthiest, strongest and tallest, with the best connections and titles. She wouldn't settle for just any firstborn son of the nobility, and both she and her father were anxious for her to actually marry into royalty.

"What is it, Father?" she asked as she came up to his side, slipping her arm around his trim waist and placing a chaste kiss on his cheek. Despite the fact the Duke had gray in the dark hair at his temples, he still appeared young and spry enough that many mistook him for her older brother than her father.

"Whom do you see out there training in the courtyard" Jupiter asked, pointing out the window.

Juno squinted a bit in the late afternoon sunlight. "I see a fat man training, Father," she said with a wrinkle of her nose.

"Ah, but that's not just any fat man, Juno, it's a very special fat man, if my thinking is correct."

Juno turned to look in her father's brown eyes, at equal height to her own. "Who is he that I should be concerned with him?"

"I believe that to be Prince Lucius."

Juno's eyes widened in surprise, and she turned back to lean forward against the window. She gasped when she saw the tall, muscular, yet chubby prince effortlessly heave a two-ton barbell onto its stand, then begin to move back toward the castle, apparently done with his weight training for the time being. His arm and leg muscles bulged and flexed as he moved, making Juno's mouth run dry. Despite his thick waist, the deposed prince had the most impressive form she had seen in a long time,...and considering all the men and boys who had tried for her hand over the past six years, that was saying something!

"I believe you are right!" Juno said softly, upon getting a better view of said prince as he grabbed his tunic and roughly pulled it on.

She turned calculating eyes to her father, and Jupiter smirked, delighted that her thoughts obviously mirrored his own.

"Is he as yet unmarried?" she asked.

"I'm not certain. I have not heard anything about him having a wife or children; however, such information is easily obtained."

"He obviously has lived in Fatlantis for too long," she said with a sneer.

"Aye, but I'm sure you can curb his appetite once he's wrapped around your finger."

Juno stepped away from her father to begin pacing his room. Jupiter leaned against the wall, crossing his arms over his developed chest, smiling as he watched his daughter's mind work.

"His scandal was more than twenty years ago, correct?" she asked as she moved her hands in front of her as she considered possibilities.

"Yes. He was approximately sixteen and got some Fatlantean girl with child. The rumors are that she took her own life rather than deal with the consequences of her actions."

Juno stopped in her pacing to face her father. "He was exiled to Fatlantis for a teenage scandal that never truly amounted to anything? Are you serious?" she asked incredulously.

Jupiter shrugged. "Such deeds warranted tougher consequences twenty years ago. I think the girl's death caused more outrage against Prince Lucius than if she had lived. However, I have heard he has kept his nose spotlessly clean since then. I have even heard from some of the other nobles that, despite the infrequent use our king makes of him, Prince Lucius has been one of the best emissaries Mountania has ever had."

"Well, that can only serve to our advantage, then, can't it, Father?"

Juno grinned at her father, who grinned just as widely back.

"Indeed, Juno. Indeed."
